sp.p: I only say 'tis not more strange to you than me. For let me be hang'd, if this same Me-Socia believ'd a word of it, till that same I-Socia beat it into my Head. He gave me such a particular Account of all that pass'd in the Army this Campaign; then he had got my very Shape and Name, so that two drops of Water are not more alike than t'other I to Me.—For when you, my Lord, sent me betimes in the Morning from the Port,—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: —I came to the Door a good while before I arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: 'Sdeath what Stuff's this?—Are ye quite mad?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Just as you see me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: The Fellow's bewitch'd, and fallen into some ill hands, since I sent him away.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Ill hands indeed; for their Fists have maul'd me confoundedly. [Shews his Face swell'd.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who beat ye so?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: T'other I beat Me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Sirrah, answer me nothing but what I ask.—First let me know who this same Socia is.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: He's your Servant.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Mine? I've one too many by you; but ne're had another Servant Socia since I was born.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: But now, Sir, I promise to shew ye another Socia as soon as you get in, a Servant of yours, Son of Davus, of my Shape, and my Age. In fine, your Socia's become double.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: These are all Riddles.—But saw ye my Wife?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I was not permitted to enter the House.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What hinder'd ye?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: That same He-Socia I've been talking of; he who so belabour'd me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What He-Socia do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I tell ye I. How often must I tell it?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Hark ye, Friend, ha'n't you been sleeping the while?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Not a Wink, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Perhaps you saw this Socia in a Dream?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I ne're us'd to dream out my Master's Commands. Awake, I saw him; awake, I see you; awake, I talk; and awake I was, when that waking Dog beat me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What Dog?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: That I-He-Socia, I tell ye. Lord, can't ye understand me?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How a plague shou'd a Man understand this ridiculous Banter?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: You'll immediately know—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: —Your other Socia, my Partner.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Follow me then; for first I'll ha' this Business clear'd.—See that all Things be brought from our Vessel as I order'd.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I'm as diligent and careful t'obey you as possible. I have not swallow'd your Commands wi' my Drink.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pray Heaven, all this don't prove true.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Alcmena, attended with Thessala, on the other side of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: How poor and short are this Life's Pleasures, if once compar'd with the Sorrows we endure? 'Tis Mans Destiny, and Heavens Pleasure, to mix our Joys with bitter Potions; and for some few Hours of Satisfaction, we meet with Ages of Ills and Troubles. I now experience it, and my self's a plain Witness of this: How short was this last Pleasure! I had the Privilege of one Nights Company with my Lord; and then, snatch'd away before the Morning. Methinks I'm the most desolate of Widows i'th' Absence o' the Man I love 'bove all the World; and his Departure carries more of my Soul away, than his Arrival brought with it: However this joys my Heart, to see him Victorious o'er his dreadful Foes, and laden with Honours; 'tis that I live upon. He's gone; but since he returns with deserved Glory, I'll patiently bear his Absence, with all the Firmness and Courage of a Woman; and shall think my Troubles well rewarded, in a Husband crown'd with the Name of Conqueror. For Valour's of all Rewards the greatest; preferable to all Things else; the sole Defender and Protector of our Liberties, Safeties, Lives, Estates, Parents, Countries, and Children. Valour carries all Vertues in it self, and all Perfections still attend the Valiant Man.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Heavens! how welcome shall I be to my Alcmena's Arms, where both our Loves are mutual; especially after such a famous Victory, beyond all Expectations, routing 'em in the first Battel by my own Command and Conduct. Certainly she'll be very impatient for my Return.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: How, Sir? D'ye think my Spouse won't be every whit as impatient for mine?

sp.speaker: Alc. discovering them.]
sp.p: O, my Lord's come!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Keep close, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: But why should he come back, when he seem'd in such haste? Was it only a Tryal? If his Design be to see how I could relish his Departure, truly he shall be welcome however.

sp.speaker: Soc. starting back.]
sp.p: O, good Sir, we had better return to our Vessel.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: We shall ha' nothing to eat here.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How came that into your Head?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Because Dinner's over already.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Why there's your Lady has din'd, by her Belly.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Po, Blockhead, I left her wi' Child when I went to the Campaign.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Then woe to poor Socia.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I'm come home in the nick of time to be worry'd to death with drawing Water for her Bath; for, according to your Account, she's just upon laying down.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pluck up a good Heart.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Do ye know what a Heart I've got? For if once I begin to manage the Bucket, Faith, Sir, I'm the very'st Rogue upon Earth, if I don't draw out the Hearts blood of the Well.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Come along, I'll have another for that Employment; fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I think, I shall better shew my Respects if I go and meet him.

sp.speaker: Amp. embracing Alcmena.]
sp.p:
Oh, how I'm charm'd to find my Alcmena in these longing Arms! whom I count beyond Comparison in Thebes, and the World counts a
Patern of all Vertue.—How has't been wi' ye, all this time? Did not ye long for my Return, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I see no wonderful Signs o' longing. I'm sure no body can out-fawn a Dog. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'm extreamly glad to find ye so well, just upon your lying down.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: In the Name of Goodness, my Lord, why should you play upon me thus? You complement as if you had not seen me lately, but were just come from the Army; and accost me like one long absent from his Wife.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: True indeed; till now I had no sight of ye.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: What makes ye say so?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: 'Tis my Custom to speak Truth.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: You don't do well to break so good a Custom. But is it for a Tryal of my Love?—Raillery apart; why so soon return'd? Was it some ill Omen, or Weather, that stay'd your going to your Army, as you lately told me?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Lately! How lately could that be?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Have ye any Design in that Question?—Very lately, just now, but a moment since.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pray how is it possible, as you say, to be so lately, and but a moment since?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: D'ye think, my Lord, I'd so meanly trifle as you do, when you pretend you were not here, and left me but just now?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: She seems much discompos'd. [Aside to Socia.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: A little Patience, Sir, till she has slept out her sleep.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: D'ye dream with your Eyes open?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: No, by my Soul, I'm throughly awake; and without dreaming, tell you all that pass'd: For I saw ye both, this Morning before Day-light.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: At what Place?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Your own House.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I ne're was there.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Do'nt be too positive, Sir; our Vessel, perhaps, brought us from the Port, and we all asleep.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Ha' you got into the same Vein too? [Angrily.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: What wou'd y'ha'me do, Sir? Don't ye know th' old Saying, Cross a Madman, and he's the Devil; humour him, and 'tis as good as Physick.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Hah, Rogue!—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Truly 'tis but reasonable to shew some Anger, since she ga' me so cold a Welcome. [Aside to Socia.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: You'd as good piss in a Bee Hive.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue.—Alcmena, answer me one Question.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: What Question? Let's hear't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Is't Madness or Pride that has infected ye?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: How came such a Question into your Head, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Because i' my former Journeys y'us'd to receive me as all other vertuous Wives do: But now I meet with a quite different Welcome.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: As I hope to live, yesterday I receiv'd y' as a Wife ought, my Lord; enquir'd after your Health, press'd your hand, and met ye with a Kiss.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Did ye speak to my Lord yesterday, Madam?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: And to you too, Socia.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: My Lord, I was in hopes o' your Honour's having an Heir; but o'my Conscience your Lady's not big with Child.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: With what then?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: With Fool.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Truly I've no such Distemper, as I hope for a safe Deliverance.—But if my Lord wou'd but gi' ye your due, Mr. Fortune Teller, you'd soon reap the mischievous Fruits o' your sawcy Predictions.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, there are Fruits too, of Lying-in Women, and Fruits too, to strengthen their Hearts, and keep 'em from swooning.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You see me here yesterday?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I say I did, if you must needs ha't so often.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: In a Dream, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Nay, we were both awake as possible.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Mercy upon me!

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: My Wife's mad.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: She's melancholly, and that's the high Road to't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: When found ye the rise o' this Disease, Alcmena?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Upo' my Soul I ne're was better, and sounder i' my Life.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why then d'ye pretend t' ha' seen me yesterday, when I put into Port but last night? There supp'd, and lodg'd all night i'the Vessel. I ne're set foot in Thebes since the Teleboan Expedition, till now we conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: 'Twas me you supp'd with, and me you lay with.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What say ye?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Nothing but truth.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: By Heaven not i'this; in other things, I know not.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Betimes i'the morning you went to your Army.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How can all this be?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Very right; she tells her Dream as 'tis fresh in memory.—But, Madam, Iove, the Disperser o' such Prodigies, ought t' have had his Cake, or his Incense offer'd this Morning. [Ieeringly.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: How sawcily the Fellow snaps me up; and you suffer him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Leave your prating, Sirrah.—You say I left ye betimes i' the morning? [To Alcmena.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Who else cou'd tell me the Particulars o' the Battel?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And heard ye o' that too?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Why truly 'twas you told me how you storm'd their chief Town, and slew King Pterelas wi' your own hands.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I tell ye so?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Yes, you; Socia heard ye.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Did you hear me tell any such thing, Socia?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Where shou'd I hear't?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Nay, let her tell ye that.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Troth, Madam, I ne're was present at any such Relation, as I know of.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: No wonder if he says as you'd have him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Come hither, Socia; look o' my Face—

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Now speak the truth without the least Flattery. Did you hear me tell her one word o' what she pretends?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Bless me! ha' you your Senses too, and ask such a Question? Faith, Sir, this is the first time I saw ye together.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Now, Madam, d'ye hear what he says?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and know't to be false.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What, believe neither Servant nor Husband?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Neither; because o' such Evidence, and the certainty o' what I affirm.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: D'y'affirm my Arrival yesterday?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: D'ye deny your Departure this Morning?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I do; and protest this is my first Appearance.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Good now, and you'll deny you ga' me the Golden Cup too, which you say was there presented ye?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Upon Honour, I neither gave it nor said it. 'Tis true, I was so design'd, and am still.—But pray who told ye o' that?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Your self was both Teller and Giver.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I beseech ye.—This is amazing, Socia, that she shou'd know o' my being presented wi' this Cup. Except you saw her, and told her all.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Let me be hang'd if I e're told, or saw her till now.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What Woman's that? [Looking on Thessala.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Wou'd y' ha' the Cup produc'd?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: It shall then.—Thessala, step into my Chamber for the Golden Cup my Lord ga'me this Morning.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Come this way, Socia.— [They walk a little on one side.] Really, if she has the Cup, the Mystery will be ten times greater to me.

div.stage: [Socia takes out a Casket from under his Cloak.]

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Can ye suppose that, when I've got it here i'the Casket seal'd wi' your own Signet.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Is the Seal whole?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Look, Sir, to be sure. [Holding it up.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Just, as I sign'd it. [Looking.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, must we deal wi' my Lady as a Person crack'd brain?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I' faith, and so we had need. For upo' my word she's over-run with Extravagancies.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: To them Thessala with a Golden Cup.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: What need o' Words? Here's Demonstration! look ye.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pray let's see't. [He takes it out and looks on't.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Come, view it well, you who so obstinately deny matter o' Fact; and be convinc'd before all the World.—Is n't it the same you were presented with?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O Heavens! Where are my Eyes? The very same upon Honour. I'm all in Confusion, Socia. [Returns the Cup.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Marry, here must be damnable Witchcraft, or the Cup's here still.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Come, break open the Casket.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p:
Why shou'd I break it open? the Seal's firm; and makes well for us.—You, my Lord, has brought
forth another Amphitryon; I, another Socia; now, if the Cup has engender'd too, we're all three double.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'll ha't broke open, and look'd into.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, look o' the Seal once more, that afterwards I mayn't be brought in for Burglary. Amphitryon looks.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Open it quickly; she'll run us down, and think us mad else.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Where think ye I shou'd ha' this, but from you who ga' me't?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: That's my business to enquire into. [Socia opens it.

sp.speaker: Soc. starting.]
sp.p: Heaven ha' mercy upo' my Soul!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What ails the Fellow?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: The Cup's flown out o' the Nest.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What say ye?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Nothing but truth.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: An unlucky truth to you, if it be gone.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Why here 'tis apparently. [Holding it up.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who gave't ye?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: The same who asks the Question.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: You're upo' the catch, my Lord. You stole slyly out o' the Ship some back-way, with the Cup, presented it to my Lady, then privately seal'd up the Casket again.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Hah! you sooth her in her Madness too.—But once more, do y' affirm I was here yesterday?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I do; and, at our first Enterview, saluted each other, and met with a Kiss.

sp.speaker: Amp. aside.]
sp.p: I cou'd ha' spar'd that Kindness.— [To her.] Proceed.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: You bath'd your self.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What next?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Sat down at the Table.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, best of all! now Catechise her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Don't interrupt, Sirrah.—On wi' your Story.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Supper was serv'd up, we sat down, and supp'd both together.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: At the same Table?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Shame on't! I don't like that Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Leave fooling.—We supp'd together; what then?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: You complain'd o'drowsiness; Supper was taken away, and together we went up to Bed.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Where did you lay?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I' the same Chamber and Bed wi' your self.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Ruin'd then!

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Stabb'd to the Heart?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: What ails ye, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Let me alone. [Turning away.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: What's done t'ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'm a miserable Man; basely dishonour'd by my Wife i' m' Absence.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: In good earnest, my Lord, why this hard Censure from your Mouth?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Am I your Lord? Prithee don't gi' me a wrong Title.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: A very pretty Bus'ness; if she has taken away his Manhood, and made him a Lady. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: What have I done, to make y' use me thus?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You declare your Crimes, then ask me how you've offended.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Is't an Offence to lye wi' m' own Husband?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Wi' me? Was there ever such prodigious Impudence? If y'had lost all Sense of Honour, sure you might ha' borrow'd o' your Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Our Family was ne're guilty o' such Crimes; and if my Honour's Ruin by your Aim, you'll lose your Labour.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Bless my Soul!—Sure you know me, Socia.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Pretty well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Didn't I sup last Night in your Vessel at th' Euboan Port?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I've s •… fficient Evidence to prove what I say.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Evidence, who are they?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Evidence I say.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What will they give in?—But, one's sufficient; for, here was no body but Socia.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Marry, I don't know what to make of all this, unless there be another Amphitryon, who in your Absence takes care o' your Business, and your Lady's too. I thought it plaguy strange to find a Deputy Socia▪ but i' faith a second Amphitryon's a greater wonder. Certainly some Inchantments ha' been practis'd upo' your Lady.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: By Heaven, and by all that's good, which Oaths to me are all sacred, I ne're gave to any Man but you, the least Liberty that cou'd call my Honour in question.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Heaven make it true.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I affirm it is, but in vain, since you won't believe.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You're a Woman, and swear too boldly.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Innocence ought to be bold, and to vindicate it self with a Confidence, and Haughtiness.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Here's Boldness enough.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: No more than becomes Vertue.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: We've your word for that. [Ieeringly.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I don't, like others, esteem a little Dirt my Portion, but my Continency, and Honour, my Moderating my Passions, my Fear of Heaven, Duty to my Parents, Love to my Kindred, Obedience to my Husband, my liberal Bounty to the Good, and my Care over the Vertuous.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I'faith, if all this be true, certainly she's the very Map of Innocence.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'm so strangely confounded, I scarce know where I am.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Certainly you must be my Lord Amphitryon still. But have a great care you don't get into the new Fashion; for here's nothing but Metamorphoses since our Arrival.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Madam, I'm resolv'd to search to the very bottom o' this Business.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Do't a Gods Name.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What say ye?—Answer me to this: Suppose I bring from the Port, your Kinsman Naucrates, who came over i' the same Vessel wi' me? If he disproves all your Assertions, what Treatment d'ye deserve then? What Plea will ye find to save your Divorce and Portion?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: If I fail i' my part, I'll urge none.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
Agreed.—Socia, Conduct these Prisoners into the House.—I'll away t' our Vessel, and bring home Naucrates.
Exit Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Now we are by our selves, Madam, tell me seriously, whether I han't within Doors a Brother Socia, just like me for all the World?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Out o' my sight, Rascal, who art fit for nothing but thy Master.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I'll vanish at your Commands. Beckons the Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Bless me! ' •… is very strange it shou'd come into my Lords H •… d t'accuse me thus wrongfully. Whate're the Matter be, my Cozen Naucrates will clear all.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Jupiter, addresses himself to the Audience, and goes on with the Prologue.

sp.p: GEntlemen, I'm still Amphitryon, and have a Servant Socia; who, when occasion serves, shall be Mercury again. My Lodgings are i'th' upper Garret, where I'm Jove as often as I please. But when e're I come down, I change my Garb, and become Amphitryon in a trice.—It's for your sakes, Gentlemen, I'm come here now, to make the Comedy compleat; and at the same time to protect poor Alcmena's Honour against her Husbands false Accusations: For 'twould be a piece o' Baseness to suffer my Crimes to fall upon her Head.—Now will I reassume Amphitryon's Person, and once more put the grand Sham upo' the whole Family: But then I'll clear all at last, assist Alcmena in due time, and at once have her deliver'd o' both mine and her Husbands Child, and that without any pain.—I order'd Mercury to be here immediately, and receive his Commands.—Now I'll go to her.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Alcmena at the other End of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Alc. to her self.]
sp.p:
The House is grown odious to m •… no •… ; since my Lord accuses me o' Dishones •… y, Shame
and Infamy. He denies plain Matters o' Fact, and exclaims against me strangely; he affirms what never was, and blames me for what I'm innocent of; after all, thinks I'll tamely sit down and bear all. But as I'm a living Soul, he's mistaken; for I'll not suffer th' unjust Scandal of Whore: No, I'll part first, unless he makes me ample Satisfaction, and swears he repents of his unjust Accusation.

sp.speaker: Iup. coming nigher.]
sp.p: That I must do in good earnest, if I ever hope for a kind Reception. For seeing my Tricks fall heavy upon Amphitryon's Head, and my Love proves injurious to this innocent Creature, I must expect some Anger and hard Words for what I'm innocent of too. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Alc. to her self.]
sp.p: Oh! here's the Person who accuses his poor Wife o' Shame, and Infamy.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Madam, I'd willingly talk wi' ye.— [She turns from him.] Why do y'avoid me?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: 'Tis my Nature to serve my Enemies so. [Angrily.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Bless me! your Enemies?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Yes truly, my Enemies; unless you'll pretend this is false too. [She frowns.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Now you're too nicely reserv'd. Offers to take her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Pray let m' alone.—I'm sure had y'either Wit or Discretion, or weren't the greatest Fool in Nature, you'd ne're hold Discourse, either in Mirth or Earnest, with the Woman you believe, and declare a Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p:
If I did, you're ne're the worse, no not in my Opinion; therefore I return to beg your Pardon, my Dear: For no Torment has been so great to me, as th' Apprehensions o' your Displeasure.—Why didst name such a thing? I'll clear all t'ye. Upon Honour, I ne're mistrusted your Fidelity; I had only a mind to try your Temper, and how you cou'd bear what I said.
'Twas all but a little harmless Raillery for sport-sake; ask Socia else.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: But why wasn't my Cozen Naucrates brought hither, as you pretended, to prove you ne're were here before?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: What's spoken in Jest, my Dear, ought never to be taken in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I'm sure there was enough to make my heart ake.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Dear Alcmena, by this fair Hand, let me beg, and intreat ye, to forgive, forget, and be pacify'd.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: M' unspotted Honour's above all Scandal; and since you've own'd me free from all base Acts, I wou'd be as free from all base Suspicions.—Farewel, keep your own Things, and let me ha' mine. Pray send my Women after me, t'accompany me. [She weeps.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Sure y' ar' n't mad?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: If you will not, I'll go alone; my Vertue shall be my Companion. [She offers to go.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Pray stay; I propose this Oath to your Discretion.—I do sincerely believe my Wife to be most Vertuous; which if I falsifie, may Iove's eternal Wrath fall upon Amphitryon's head.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Ah, his Mercy rather.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: I hope 'twill prove so; for I'm sure I've truly sworn.—Now I hope you're satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: I'm glad of't.—A Man in his life-time, meets with a thousand such Accidents as these, sometimes Pleasures, othertimes Troubles, by and by Fallings out, then Reconciliations again. But whenever these little Love. Quarrels happen, and those made up, the pleasing Passion's doubl'd.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Your ill Words might well ha' been spar'd, my Lord: but if you make me such Satisfaction, I ought to forget all.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Pray order all my Sacred Vessels to be got ready, to perform those Vows I made i'the Campaign, if ever I got safe home again.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Iup. to the Servants within.]
sp.p: Send out Socia there; I must send him for Blepharon, our Ships Pilot, t'invite him to Dinner.—But not a mouthful shall Socia get; and here'll be rare sport when I come to grapple with Amphitryon, and send him packing. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: I wonder what he's talking of t' himself.—But the Door goes.—Here comes Socia.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: O, my Lord, I'm ready: if there be occasion, lay your Commands upo' me, and I'll obey 'em.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: You're come in good time.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, is't Peace or War between ye?—I'm glad to see ye both in a peaceable Posture, and 'tis a great Satisfaction to me. Truly 'tis a good Servants Duty to sympathise with his Master, to be as he is, look as he looks, be sad when he's sad, and merry when he's pleas'd.—But, good Sir, tell me; is there an amicable Accommodation?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: You jeer now; you know we were only in laughing.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: In laughing, said ye? I' faith, I thought ye never more in earnest i'your Life.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: I've satisfy'd her, and made my peace.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Excellent, introth.

sp.speaker: Iup,
sp.p: I've a Sacrifice to make, according to my Vows.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I perceive as much.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: You must go to Blepharon, the Pilot of our Ship, and desire him, from me, to be here at the Ceremony, and take a Dinner wi' me.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I'll be back again before you can think me there.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Well, make haste then. Exit Socia.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Shall I go in, my Lord, and help to get Things ready as occasion shall serve?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: By all means, Madam; and prepare all Things as well as you can.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Come in as soon as you please, and you'll find nothing out of order.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Very well▪ this is like a loving Wife.

So, both Lady and Servant over-reach'd, in taking me for Amphitryon: Mistaken to some purpose!—Now, immortal Socia, be ready at hand, (you hear me tho' you're absent) and don't fail o' finding some Artifice to drive away Amphitryon when he comes: Remember't. I'd ha' ye trifle away the time with him, while I conform my self to this same borrow'd Wife. Don't deceive me, but serve me according to my Intentions; and, besure be in readiness t' assist me, the mean time that I'm sacrificing to my self.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mercury at the further End of the Stage, running in great haste.

sp.p: ROom here! Clear the way! All the World make room! and let not a Soul be so desperately mad as to stop my Journey—

div.stage: •… le addresses himself to the Spectators, and finishes the Prologue.

sp.p:
TRoth, Gentlemen, why shou'dn't my Deityship gi' me the same Priviledge o' threatning the Mob, when they stand i' my way, as the Slaves in Comedies have? Their vast haste is only for a Vessel safely arriv'd, an old Fellow upo' the fret, or so; but I, Jove's Messenger, and sent by his Commands, ha' more reason to call for room, and clear all before me.—My Father he calls, I follow; his Word's my Law, and I obey him with all the Submission of a dutiful Son. I sooth him in his Wenching, encourage him, pimp for him, counsel him, and rejoyce with him; and whene're he receives a Pleasure, it proves ten times as much to me. Do's he long for a Girl? He do's well and wisely to satisfie his longing; a Thing all wise Men ought t' observe, provided it be safe. Now 'tis my Father's Will and Pleasure, t' impose upon Amphitryon: Troth I do't nobly.—
I'll do't immediately, Gentlemen, before your Faces. I'll whip on a Chaplet, pretend to be drunk, and get my self above. From thence I'll send him with a Vengeance, as soon as he approaches, and make him dry drunk, I'll warrant him. Next, Socia must go to Pot; and be condemn'd for what I did. But what's that to me? 'Tis my Bus'ness t' obey my Father's Commands, and observe his Pleasure.— [Looking about.] O yonder comes Amphitryon. I shall make admirable Sport with him, if you'll please to favour me with your Silence.—I'll in, and adorn my self like a Drunkard: Then I'll ascend th' House, and from thence do his Bus'ness for him. Exit Mercury.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Amphitryon at the further End of the Stage, out of Breath.

sp.p: I cou'dn't meet wi' Naucrates at his Vessel for my Life, nor at home neither, or so much as a Soul i' the City who had seen him. I've been hunting for him through every Alley, among th' Armorers and Perfumers, at the Change, the Shambles, the Race-Ground, the Markets, th' Apothecaries and Barbers Shops, and at all the Temples in Town. I'm wearied off my Legs, and no Naucrates to be found high nor low.—I'll e'e •… go home, and make a further Enquiry o'my Wife, to find out this Person that dishonour'd my Bed i' my Absence. 'Tis more than Death to me to let the Bus'ness thus hang in suspence.— [He goes to his door, and tries to open it.] They've secur'd the Doors; very fine! This is like the rest o' their Tricks; but I'll make 'em hear me.— [He knocks.] Open the Door! Soho, within there!— [Knocks louder.] No body t' open the door?

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Mercury appears above, crown'd with a Garland, and pretending to be drunk.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Who's at the Door?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I; what I?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I, I tell ye. [Knocking again.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sure the Devil and his Dam has possest ye, for bouncing at our Doors.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How?—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So, as to make y' a poor Rogue as long as you've a day to live.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Socia!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That's my Name indeed; except you think I've lost my Memory.—What's your Bus'ness?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Rascal, ha' ye th' Impudence t' enquire after my Bus'ness?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes marry have I.—Why, you Blockhead, you've almost thrown the Door off the Hinges. D'ye think our Doors are made at the publick Charge?—What makes ye stare so, Bufflehead? What's your Business, I say? And who are ye?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Varlet, how dare y' ask such a Question? Thou cursed branded Rogue! As I'm a living Soul, I'll drub ye to some tune for all your Sauciness?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Certainly you must ha' been a prodigal Dog in your time.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why so, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Because i'your old Days you're forc'd to come begging to me for a Beating.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Thy Back, Slave, shall soundly pay for all this.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then I shall sacrifice—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Something to your Worships Pa •… e.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You, Jail-bird?—If I live and do well, I'll hang y' up by the heels, wi' your Skin stripp'd o'e •… your Ears, and make a Sacrifice o' you.—Out o' your Castle, you cursed Rascal.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Poor Phantom, dost think to fright me wi' big Words?—But if you don't take ye to your Heels quickly, or offer to knock, or touch the Door with a finger, I'll hit ye such a douce o' the Chaps wi' this Tile, as shall dash out your Teeth and Tongue together. [Holding up a Tile.

sp.speaker: Amp
sp.p: Damn'd Villain, Will ye shut m' out o' m' own House? and keep me from knocking at m' own Door? I'll make the Doors fly presently. [He bounces at the Door.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: D'ye persist, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes, Rogue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Have at your Corps then. He throws down a Tile upon him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Cursed Slave, throw upo' your Lord and Master? If I do once lay hands on ye, I'll make ye a perpetual Example t' all Rogues.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Y' ought to get your Brains clear'd, y' old Fool!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: For calling me your Servant.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What if I do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then you'd better be hang'd; for I own no Master but Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Amp. aside, looking upon himself.]
sp.p: Sure I ha'n't lost my Shape? I'm startl'd at Socia's denying me. But I'll try him further.— [To him.] Hark ye, tell me, whom do I seem? Is't not plain that I'm Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Amphitryon? A Mad-man rather Didn't I tell ye, Old Fool, that your Brains shou'd be clear'd, when y' ask'd others who y'are.—Begone, I advise ye, and make no Disturbance here, for my Lord Amphitryon's just come home from the Campaign, and retir'd with his Lady to Bed.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alcmena.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: But what Man is't?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How often must I tell ye?—My Lord Amphitryon. Trouble us no further.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who do's he lye with?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Have a care your fooling wi' me don't bring an old House upo' your Head.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Nay, good Socia, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Now you're a Peg lower.—With Alemena then.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Lye with her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, I think so; and upon her too.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'm a lost Man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What he calls Loss, is clear Gains. For, to let out ones Wife, is as good as farming out a barren piece o' Ground to good Husbandmen. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Socia!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What a plague mean ye by Socia?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Don't ye know me, Slave?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, for an impertinent quarrelsome Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Still i' that vein?—Am not I thy Master Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Some Tom a Bedlam I think, not Amphitryon. How often must I tell ye so? Wou'd ye hea •… 't once more? My Master Amphitryon's now at Bed with Alcmena.—Stay here any longer, I'll send him out with a Devil t'ye.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: That I'd fain see.—Pray Heaven my publick Services ben't rewarded wi' loss o' Country, House, Wife, Family, and Shape too. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I'll send him t'ye; but i' the mean time retire a while. For I believe the Sacrifice is ready, and they'll to Dinner presently. But if you chance to be impertinent, you'll go nigh to be sacrific'd your self. [Mercury retires.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Amphitryon alone, walking discontentedly about his Door.

sp.p: Heavens bless me! What strange Madness has seis'd upon our Family? What Prodigies have I seen since this last Journey? Now I'm apt to credit the old Fable as true, that in Arcadia, th' Attick People were transform'd into savage Beasts, so that their Parents and Friends cou'd never know 'em after.— [He stands in amaze.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Blepharon and Socia at the further End of the Stage, talking together.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: —How's this, Socia? 'Tis the strangest Story I ever heard. Did ye meet with another Socia at the Door just o' your own Shape, say ye?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Yes.—But hark ye, Sir; since I've spawn'd another Socia, and my Lord another Amphitryon, who knows but you may another Belpharon. Wou'd to Heaven you were but as well convinc'd, at th' Expence of a swell'd Chaps, broken Teeth, and an empty Belly as I am. For t'other I-Socia, that am yonder, swindg'd me, and made a poor Rogue o' me.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Prodigious, I swear!—But let's mend our Pace tho', for yonder's his Lordship staying for us; and truly my Stomach begins to wamble.

sp.speaker: Amp. to himself.]
sp.p:
—But why do I mention Foreign Prodigies; since we're told stranger Stories of our City's Founder? This mighty Prince, in quest of Europa, slew the dreadful Monster, from whose scatter'd Teeth sprung Arm'd Troops, in order rang'd, where Brothers baited Brothers to Death. After all, Epirus saw the same great Person and his Wife, crawl about in Serpents
Shapes. All this was great Iove's Will, and the Decree of Fate. The best of our Family have had their noble Exploits rewarded with dire Misfortunes. 'Tis my Destiny, and I must sustain these Shocks o' Misery, and take off these unsufferable Potions.—

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Mr. Blepharon! [Fearfully.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: My Mind misgives me plaguely.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Why.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Look ye; yonder he walks before his Door, waiting like a Parasite to bid his Lordship Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: 'Tis only to catch himself a Stomach.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Very ingeniously contriv'd: So he has secur'd his Doors for fear it shou'd come too soon.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: You're i' the jeering Vein.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Nor yet i' the snarling.—Observe a little, if you please.—He's talking to himself, if I knew what 'tis; and I believe he's hammering at some plaguy Business.—I'll listen to his Discourse.—Stand still a while.

sp.speaker: Amp. to himself.]
sp.p: —O how I fear that the Gods shou'd bereave me o' th' Honour o' this Victory. I find my whole Family possest with strange Extravagancies. Then my Wifes Disloyalty and Infamy goes to the heart o' me. But the Cup quite startles me; for 'twas as well Seal'd as possible.—How can it be? My Wife relates all the Particulars o' the Battel, particularly that Pterelas was slain by m' own Hands.—Ho, ho, I've found out the Trick at last. This was all Socia's Roguery, who but just now had th' Impudence to shut m' out o' my own House;—

sp.speaker: Soc. overhearing.]
sp.p: So, my Name's brought up, but with a plaguy harsh Sound.—Pray let's keep off a little while, till his whole Passion be discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: How you will for that.

sp.speaker: Amp. to himself.]
sp.p: —But cou'd I but lay hands o' that Rascal, I'd teach him to deceive, abuse, and hector his own Master. [Very angrily.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: D'ye hear him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: The Storm is just breaking upo' my Shoulders.—We must go up to him; for you know th' old Saying—

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: I know nothing o' your Sayings; but I've a nigh guessing at your Sufferings.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: 'Tis an old Proverb, That an empty Belly and a slack Guest, makes one as mad as the Devil.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Very true, we'll meet him immediately.—My Lord Amphitryon!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: 'Tis Blepharon's Voice. I wonder what's his Business wi' me. However, he comes very luckily to be a Witness o' my Wifes Baseness.— [Here they meet and joyn Discourse.] How now, Blepharon; what ha' you to say to me?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Has your Honour forgot you sent Socia t' our Vessel this Morning t'invite me to Dinner?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I ne're so much as thought of't.—But where's that Villain?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Socia.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: There he is. [Pointing to him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Just before ye.—Don't ye see him?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Passion blinds me, and this Rascal has distracted me.—I'll sacrifice ye, you Dog; you mustn't think t' escape.— [Offers at Socia, Blepharon holds him.] Prithee let me come at him.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Hear a little, I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Speak, I do hear.— [He breaks loose, and strikes Socia.] Take that, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Why this Usage, Sir?—Ha'n't I been quick enough?—If I had got Pacolet's Horse, I cou'dn't ha' came sooner.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Hold, good Sir; we came as great a Pace as we cou'd.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
A Hare's or Snails pace, 'tis all one; I'm resolv'd
to beat the Rascal as long as he can stand.—Imprimis, for the House-top;—Item, for the Tile;—Item, for shutting me out;—Item, for your mocking me;—Item, for your sawcy Tongue;— [Beats him at each word.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: What has he done, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Done, quoth a?—He shut the Door upo' me, and shamefelly abus'd me from the House-top.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes you, who so insolently threatn'd me if I offer'd to touch the Door.—Dog, d'ye deny't too?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Why shou'd n't I? Here's a sufficient Witness to justify't; the same you sent m' in all haste t' invite to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who sent ye, Impudence?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: You, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: When, I pray?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Just now, very lately, but a moment since; when you and your Lady were reconcil'd within.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: The Fellow's bedevil'd sure.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I defie the Devil and all his Works.—You order'd me to clean all the Vessels, for you had a Sacrifice t' offer: and then you sent me for this Gentleman, to take a Dinner wi' ye.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Let me perish, if e'er I set step within Doors, or sent him any where.—Where did ye leave me last, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: At home wi' your Lady; from whence I hasten'd to the Port, invited him as y' order'd me, and here we are. I ne're had one Glimpse o' ye since then.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Impudent Dog, wi' my Wife?—Now you mustn't think t'escape my Hands. [He offers at him.

sp.speaker: Soc. avoiding him.]
sp.p: Mr. Blepharon!—

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Good my Lord, spare him for my sake, and hear me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Well, speak your Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p:
He has been telling o' me wonderful strange Stories;
and perhaps some Juggler or Sorcerer, has bewitch'd your Family. Y' had best make a strict Enquiry into the Business, and not use the poor Fellow like a Dog, before you know a jot o' the matter.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Come then, let's enter the House; I must ha' ye for a Witness i' my Wifes Case.

sp.speaker: Jup. appearing at the Door.]
sp.p: Who's that made our Doors fly after such a vengenable rate? Who dares cause such a Riot before my House? If I catch him, I'll sacrifice his Soul to the Teleboan Ghosts.— [He comes forward.] Nothing goes well wi' me to day. I left Blepharon and Socia, to hunt up my Cozen Naucrates; him I can't find high nor low, and t'other two I've quite lost.—O here they are.—I'll go to 'em to know how Matters stand.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: O, Mr. Blepharon, that's my Master that comes from the House; 'tis this is the Sorcerer.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Bless me! what do I see?—This isn't He, but th' Other. And if this be Amphitryon, troth that can't, unless he be double.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Here's Blepharon and Socia together: I'll begin with them first.— [They meet.] Are ye come at last, Socia? I begin t' have a Stomach.

sp.speaker: Soc. to Belpharon.]
sp.p: Didn't I tell ye this was the Sorcerer?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No, that's he, my Theban Neighbours, that has corrupted my Wife, and heap'd Dishonour upo' my Head.

sp.speaker: Soc. to Iupiter.]
sp.p: My Lord, your Stomach may be empty, but I'm sure I'm come wi' my Belly full o' Cuffs.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Still i' that Humour, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Soc. to Amphitryon.]
sp.p: Get ye to the Devil, ye damn'd Sorcerer.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Call me Sorcerer, Slave? [Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: How dare you ha' th' Insolence to beat my Servants?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Thine?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Yes Mine.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You lye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Go in, Socia, and hasten the Dinner; while I make an Example o' this Fellow.

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: I go, Sir.— [To himself, going off.] I fancy th' Enterview between This-Amphitryon and That-Amphitryon, will be just as civil as that between I-Socia and Me-Socia. Well, the time they're squabbling abroad, I'll in and ransack the Kitchin, lick all the Platters clean, and suck my sweet Face with all the Liquor I can find.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Dare ye gi' me the Lye?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes that I dare, thou cursed Corrupter o' my Family.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: For that Affront, I'll throatle ye. [Takes him by the Collar.

sp.speaker: Amp. striking at him.]
sp.p: Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: You shou'd ha' had more Forecast then.

sp.speaker: Amp. struggling.]
sp.p: Help, good Blepharon.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: They're so alike, I can't tell which side to take; but I'll part the Fray as well as I can.—Pray One-Amphitryon, don't murder Tother Amphitryon.—Good now let go.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Call ye him Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Why not? He was formerly single, now he's become double. Tho' indeed you're the Man, he's still the Person: therefore pray let go.

sp.speaker: Iup. letting go.]
sp.p: Well then.—But in earnest d'ye take him for Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Faith both of ye.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Heavens bless me! Where got ye that Shape o' mine? [Aside.] But I'll pump him.—Are you Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Are you he that deny't?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I am; since there's ne're another Amphitryon in all Thebes.—

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: But me, I grant ye; and, Blepharon, be you Judge.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: I'll clear the Business by Tokens, if I can.—Do you answer first then. [To Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: What Orders did ye gi' me before the Battel wi' the Taphians?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: When the Vessel was ready, not to part from the Stern a moment,—

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: —Because if our Army were routed, I might secure m' own Retreat.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I order'd ye besides, t' have an Eye to the great Bag o' money I left wi' ye.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Hold a little, Sir; that's a Question for me to ask.—Do you know the Sum?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Yes, it amounted to fifty Attick Talents.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Right to a Farthing.—How many pieces of Gold were there? [To Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Two thousand.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: And twice as many Brass.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: You've both nick'd it.—Certainly one o' ye must ha' been enclos'd i' the Bag.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: But observe Sir; to clear all, this right hand slew Pterelas; I receiv'd his Spoils; his Drinking-Cup I had in a Casket; I gave't my Wife, and this day did I bath with her, sacrifice with her, and lye with her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
That Word stabs me. I'm almost distracted: I sleep and dream wi' my Eyes open, and perish wi' my Health and Senses about me.—Certainly I am that Amphitryon, Gorgophon's Grand-child, General o' the Thebans, Creon's Friend, Conqueror of the Teleboans, o' th'
Acarnanians, and Taphians, and by my Courage slew their King. There I made Cephalus Governour, the great D •… oneus's Son; and—

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: —There by my Valour, defeated those Ravagers, who had kill'd Electryon, and my Wife's Brothers; wasted Achaia, Etolia, and Phocis; and scour'd th' Ionian, Egean, and Cretian Seas from their Privateers.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Bless me! I can't believe my self, he has so hit upon every Punctilio.—What say you, Blepharon?

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: There's one Proof behind; if that be made out, ye must certainly be double.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: O, you mean the Scar o' my right Arm, caus'd by the Wound Pterelas ga' me.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Well thought on.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: D'ye see?—look here. [Uncovers his Arm.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Uncover both o' ye, that I may see. Amphitryon uncovers.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: We have; now look.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Heavens, what do I see? Both mark'd i' the same Arm, i' the same Place, and exactly with the same Scar, a little reddish just like a late Wound. The Proofs are equal, the Determination unfix'd, and I can go no further.—You two must decide the Bus'ness between both, for my Affairs call me away.—Never did I see such a strange sight i' my born days.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Good Blepharon, don't leave me in distress, but be my Counsellor a while.

sp.speaker: Ble.
sp.p: Adieu.—What signifies a Counsellor when he knows not which side to plead of?

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: I'll go in. Alcmena cries out.

div.head: SCENE VIII.

sp.p:
Ruin'd for ever! Abandon'd by my Friends and and Counsellors. But by Heaven, this damn'd Impostor
sha'n't abuse me unreveng'd, whoe'er he be. I'll immediately to the King, and acquaint him with the whole Bus'ness. As I hope to live, I'll severely punish this Hellish Sorcerer. who has play'd such villanous Tricks wi' my whole Family.— [Looking round about him.] But where is he?—O' my Soul, gone in; and I believe, to my Wife.—Did Thebes e'er produce a greater Wretch?—What Course can I take? All the World deny me, and make a Mock o' me as they please. 'Tis fix'd at last; I'll break in upon 'em, and the first living Creature I meet, whether Maid or Man, Wife or Stallion, nay Father or Grandfather, I'll murder upo' the Spot. Tho' mighty Iove, and all the Gods, shou'd interpose, I'd perfect my Design. Now I'll enter the House.—

div.stage: He goes to the Door; it thunders; he shakes, and falls into a Swoon.
div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.
It Thunders and Lightens between the Acts.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Bromia in a great Fright. Amphitryon in a Swoon upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p:
ALL my Hopes and Means o' Safety are fled; and I've nothing to support my drooping Spirits, since all Things, even Seas, Earth, and Heaven, seem to conspire t'overwhelm and ruin me.—Mercy upo' me! What shall I do? I've seen so many
Prodigies within.—O wretched! ready to swoon; O for a little Water, my Heart chills and faints away, my Head ake •… , my Ears and Eyes fail me, and I'm the saddest shiftless Creature upon Earth; such strange Things befell my Lady.—For when she was going of her Labour, she invok'd the Gods. Lord, what Voices and Noises, what Clashes and Flashes; how suddenly, how frequently, how terribly it thunder'd! Every Soul fell flat at the Greatness o' the Claps. At the same time a mighty Voice was heard, crying, Alcmena, Succour's at hand, shake off all dread; the great King of Heaven's come to you and your Family's Protection. Rise all, who fell at the terror o' my Voice. At that I got up; and the House appeared so very bright, that methought 'twas all in Flames. My Lady she call'd me, which r •… is'd new Fears, suspecting her Safety. I went in all haste to know her Pleasure; where I found her happily deliver'd o' two Boys, and that without the least Suspicion or Knowledge of any of us.—But what's here? What old Gentleman's this who lies before our Door? Is he Thunder-struck by Iupiter?—Really, I believe 'tis so.—Bless me, he seems dead!—I'll go find who 'tis.—O, 'tis my Lord Amphitryon.— [She stirs him.] My Lord!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Amphitryon comes out of his Swoon.

sp.speaker: Amp. stirring a little.]
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Rise, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Gi' me your hand, my Lord. [She takes hold of him.

sp.speaker: Amp. looking up.]
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Your Maid Bromia.

sp.speaker: Amp. rising up.]
sp.p: I tremble all over; Iove has so stunn'd me.—I'm just as tho I had been at Hell.—Why came y' out?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: We, poor Souls, were in as great a Fright as you, we saw so many Prodigies within Doors.—Alas, my Lord, I ha'n't yet recover'd my Senses.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Come, let's talk wi' ye.—Do you indeed know me for your Master Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: See that you be certain of't.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: She's th' only unmad Person'o' my Family.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, we're none of us mad.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'm sure my Wifes base Disloyalty has made me so.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I'll soon change your Opinion i' that point, my Lord; and in few Words shew ye most apparent Proofs and Tokens, of both your Lady's Goodness and Fidelity.—First, you must know, she's brought to bed o' two Boys.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How, o' two Boys? [More concernedly.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Heavens be favourable!—

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Let me speak, and I'll tell ye how tender the Gods ha'been o'your Lady and the whole Family.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Speak then.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: When my Lady began to go of her Labour, and perceiv'd th' Approach o' th' usual Pains; with her Hands wash'd, and Head cover'd, she implor'd th' Assistance o' the Gods. Immediately it thunder'd so dreadfully, we first thought the whole House wou'd ha' fallen. Then every thing shin'd so gloriously, as if they were made o' Gold.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pray ease me a little, now you've deceiv'd me enough.—What follow'd?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I' the mean time, your Lady was deliver'd, and truly without any Pains, for not a Groan, or the least Complaint, was heard to come from her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I'm glad o' that, whate'er she has deserv'd at my Hands.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Those things apart, and hear the rest.—After her Delivery, she gave us both the Children to wash. We took 'em, and the Boy that sell to my share, was so big, and withal so vastly strong, that we cou'dn't bind him in his Blankets.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: These are Wonders indeed; if all be true, I do not question my Wifes particular Assistance from above.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: You'll say there are greater behind.—After he was laid in his Cradle, two hugeous great Serpents came rolling down the Water-Spout into the Chamber, both rearing up their Heads—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Lack a day!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: You needn't fear any thing.—The Serpents casting their Eyes about, and spying the Children, immediately made for the Cradles. Upon this, I drew 'em up and down, backwards and forwards, terribly afraid o' the Children, and my self too, they pursu'd 'em so fiercely. When the Child, I told y'of, saw this, he immediately started out of his Cradle, fell furiously upon 'em, and suddenly grasping each Serpent in his Hand,—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: 'Tis wonderful strange.—This is such a dreadful Business, as sets me a shaking all over.—But what's next? Proceed.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: —He destroy'd both the Serpents at once. In the mean time, my Lady was call'd with a loud Voice by—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: —Iove, the great King of Heaven and Earth, who openly declar'd he had layn wi' my Lady i' your Absence, and how that very Child who slew the Serpents was his; th' other, yours.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: In good troth, I like this well enough, to be Sharer wi' Iove himself in his good Fortunes.—Go in, and get all the Vessels ready for a Sacrifice quickly, that I may thank him for his Favours with a great many Victims. Exit Bromia.

I'll immediately to the Divine Tiresias, consult him in what's fittest to be done; and tell him the whole Business from the Beginning to the Ending.— [He is going off, and it thunders again.] But what's the meaning o' this tho?—How dreadfully it thunders!—Heavens bless me!

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Jupiter descends in a Machine, in his own proper Shape.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.p: Courage, Prince Amphitryon; I'm come at last to calm all yours and your Families Troubles. Shake off all Fears. Enquire nothing o' Divines and Prophets, for I, great Iove, can better tell of past and future Things than they.—First, I enjoy'd Alcmena, by which she prov'd wi' Child; you had left her wi' Child too, when you went into the Campaign; of which two, she is brought to bed at once. That one that sprung from me, by his renown'd Acts shall gain immortal Honour. As for Alcmena, receive her to your former Favour. She has n't deserv'd the least Reproach you gave her; for she cou'dn't resist my Power.—Now I'll return to Heaven.
I'll obey your great Commands, and humbly beg the Performance o' your Promises.—I'll now to my Wife, and let old Tiresias alone.—
Gallants, for Honour's Sake, and Great Iove's Cause, We hope you'll crown us with one loud Applause.

div.head: REMARKS UPON AMPHITRYON.
div.p: THE Subject of this Play is the most single that can possibly be, it being only the Birth of Hercules, and likewise the most noble of all the Comedies of the Ancients; not only for the bringing forth of such a Hero, but also for its Attendance by no less than two Gods, and with Thunders and Lightnings. This Subject, tho' great, is naturally very barren, especially if compared with many others; but this makes the Poet's Art appear still greater, in finding Incidents sufficient for a whole Play, when he had so little matter to work upon: and in the natural Management of those, he is admirable.

div.head: The PROLOGUE.
div.p: THE Prologue is spoken by Mercury, not only because he was the most proper Person to say and relate such Things as the Poet had most occasion for; but likewise, because it wou'd not have been so probable for another Person to have been abroad at that time of Night.

Pag. 3. lin. 17. &c. By Jove's Orders I came, Mercury's my Title, sent hither by my Father to beg your Attention.] Mercury, being in Disguise, and not in a Machine, as soon as he cou'd take breath after his long-winded Sentence, he tells the Spectators who he is. For tho, from that Sentence, they might pretty well guess at him, (more perhaps from his Offices than his Oratory) yet the Poet takes care to make every thing perfectly clear, and intelligible, to the Spectators; that, above all things, they might never be at a Loss as to the Plot.

Pag. 5. l. 3. And I'll make it a Hodge-podge, a Tragi-Comedy.] Faciam ut commixta sit Tragico-comaedia. This is the only Play among the Ancients, that was call'd Tragi Comedy; and this but in jest neither. But Plautus meant no such thing as we do by our Word Tragi-Comedy, as appears by the four following Verses: For always among the Ancients, the Representation of Kings and Great Mens Actions, made a Tragedy, and those of Common Persons, Comedy, whether the Catastrophe's were prosperous or not, in either. If I had translated it, a Tragical-Comedy, perhaps it might have been nigher the Author's Design, and as agreeable to the Comical Humour of him who spoke it.

Ibid. l. 8. &c. T' order the Guards t' inspect Pit, Box, and Gallery, and if they find any suborn'd to clap an Actor, to take his Cloak for a Pawn.] Ut conquisitores singuli in subsellia eant per totam caveam, spectatoribus, si cui fautores delegatos viderint, uti iis in caveâ pignus capiantur togae. The Romans were so great Encouragers of Plays, that they constantly order'd a Reward for him who play'd his Part best, which was paid him by the Edils, who were sworn to do Justice; and this often caus'd great Contests and Parties among 'em. I translated, Conquisitores, Guards; Subsellia, and totam caveam, Pit, Box, and Gallery; and Togae, Cloak, because they are the same in effect. I always take the like Liberty in such Cases, and that without any Design of changing the Scene to London.

Ibid. l. penuit. &c. A year ago, when the Players invok'd him in a pitiful Farce, he came to their Assistance.] Etiam histriones annô cùm in proscenio hic Iovem invocârunt, venit: auxilio eis fuit. Some read it, Nannio cùm in proscenio, supposing it an Allusion to a Play call'd Nannium proscenium, from a famous Courtizan of that name: But this is very doubtful; and tho', questionless, it is a sharp Reflection upon some Play in those times; yet, on what, is uncertain. What Liberty is taken in the Translation, is only to make the Satyr of it more intelligible.

Pag. 6. l. 5. First, this City is call'd Thebes; &c.] Here begins a Narration of all that was done before the opening of the Stage. This was Plautus's way in the rest of his Prologues, a thing which Terence never did; and truly Plautus is not to be commended for this; for it may seem to argue a want of Dexterity in doing of it by the Actors Mouths. But since the Prologue is no part of the Play, all being intire and compleat without it; and if these Narrations foretel nothing, like those of Euripides, their principal Fault then is, their being wholly Impertinent.

Pag. 7. l. 15. &c. Now, to distinguish us easily, I ha' little Wings upo' my Hat, and my Father a golden Tuft upon his.] This is a second Instance of Plautus's Care of preventing all manner of Obscurity, or Confusion, in the Spectators; and tho' it is here done with no great Address, (since 'tis all in a Prologue) yet it may serve for a hint of the great Exactness of the Ancients in this Point; whereas the Moderns fail in nothing more than this; and by that means often miss of Success in their greatest Beauties.

div.head: Scene the First.
div.p: PAg. 8. l. 8, &c. Out o' which damn'd Kitchin, to morrow must I be dish'd up for the Whipping-Post.] Inde cras è promtuariâ cellâ depromar ad flagrum. The Joak of this cannot easily be preserv'd in our Language; which chiefly consists in the double Signification of the Word Depromo, which is either to Draw, or to Take, or else a proper Term in Cookery, such as, to Dish, to Serve up, or the like.

Pag. 10. l. 7, &c. Madam, at our first happy Arrival at th' Enemies Country, &c.] Here begins an admirable Narration of a Battel; excellent, first, for the perfect Compleatness of the Description in so few Words, with an Air of Grandure, which makes it more diverting in a Servants mouth; but more especially, for the extraordinary Address of the Poet by finding such an ingenious Pretext for letting the Spectators know a thing so very necessary for their understanding the Plot, and that by the mouth of a single Person; so, both seriously informing, and comically delighting 'em the same time. If any object, that the Language is too good for a Servant; it may be reply'd, that Socia says not a word but what he heard from others, and what he says now, is only to have his Speech perfect.

Pag. 12. l. 21, &c. Except that night I had the Strapado, and rid the Woodden Horse till Morning.] Nisi item unam, verberatus quam pependi perpetem. Slaves, when they were beaten, were often hung up by the Legs or Hands, and kept in that Posture for a considerable while. For the Liberty I have taken, see the latter part of the fourth Remark upon the Prologue.

Pag. 13. l. 6. This may be some Rogue to steal my Cloak off my Back.] Illic hoc homo denuo volt pallium detexere.
The Word Detexere, is a Weavers Term, signifying to Put on to the Loom, and the like. Now Socia seeing Mercury in a remarkable Posture, with his hands lifted up, he pleasantly intimates as tho' he had stood ready to take his Cloak, and new weave it for him; but this is not easily preserv'd in our Tongue. I believe it wou'd have done better, and nigher to the Author's Design, if I had translated it, I'm afraid this Fellow has some great Business with my Cloak.

Ibid. l. 24. Dissociate me to Quintus.] Quintus fiam è Sosiâ. The Jest of this, in the Original, is much greater than in the Translation: For it was usual among the Romans, to call their Sons by the Names of Primus, Secundus, Tertius, Quartus, Quintus, Sextus, &c. according to their Births; as likewise their Daughters by the Names of Prima, Secunda, Tertia, Quarta, &c.
Pag. 14. l. 21. Far enough lately.] Verùm longè binc abfuit. As Madam Dacier observes, it is Socia that says this, and not Mercury, as it is in all the common Books.

Pag. 15. l. 19, &c. Whither away, Sirrah? you that carry Fire i' your Lantborn.] Quò ambulas, tu, qui Vulcanum in cornu conclusum geris? I do not see how the Comicalness of this Passage can be preserv'd in our Tongue.

Ibid. l. 27, &c. Sirrah, you'll be kick'd. Soc. You lye, Sir, for once.] Verbero. So. Mentiris n •… nc jam. The Jest here is wholly lost in the Translation, which consists in the double meaning of the Word Verbero; which is either a Noun, signifying, A Slave that deserves to be beaten; or a Verb, signifying, I beat you. Now Mercury us'd it in the former Sense, and Socia took it in the latter; and tho' it be but an ordinary Jest, it was agreeable enough to Socia's Character.

Pag. 16. l. 1, &c. Sirrah, I shall stop that damn'd foul Mouth o' yours. Soc. 'Tis past your skill, Sir. 'Tis kept as well and as clean as any Mans.] Ego tibi istam hodie scelestam comprimam linguam. So. Haud potes: bene pudicéque asservatur. This is exactly of the same Stamp with the last; playing upon the double meaning of the Word
Comprimo, which signifies, to Stop, Stay, or Repress; as likewise, to lye with a Woman. It was us'd in the former Sense by the first, and taken in the latter by the l •… st; and has nothing of that ill meaning which the Commentators and others imagine, they being most certainly in the wrong. I have more successfully translated, or rather imitated, this than the last, by making the Opposites, Foul and Clean, as he had done Comprimo and Pudicè; especially since, I'll stop your foul Mouth, is as common a Phrase among us, as Comprimam linguam was among the Romans.

Ibid. l. 19. I shall exalt your Worship to the Honour.] Faciam ego hodie te superbum. Some think that the Word Superbum, here signifies Death, and Auferere, immediately after, being carry'd in a Coffin, or the like; and others think Superbum, a great Swelling, by the Blows he wou'd give him. But the way that I have done it, seems to me to be much the more natural Sense, and to have the most Wit in it.

Pag. 17. l. 4, &c. You came wi' your Feet, not wi' your Cloaths.] Certe pedibus, non tunicis venis. This, in its self, is one of the meanest Jests in the Play; but considering that Mercury had to deal with a mean, cavilling, quibbling Fellow, who wrested all his Words to a wrong Meaning, (particularly his Verbero and Comprimo) and one whom he was to banter all the ways he cou'd, it seems proper enough in this place.

Pag. 21. l. 8, &c. He has erected my Statue i' my Lifetime; I ll be sworn no body will honour me so much after I'm dead and gone.] Vivo fit, quod nunquam quisquam mortue faciet mihi. This is Wit in all Languages.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p:
This Scene is a Part of the Prologue; for which our Poet is not to be excus'd, not only for placing of it here, and so confounding the Spectators Attention by mingling their Concerns with the Actors, but likewise
foretelling in it, the Catastrophe, which ought to have been carefully conceal'd from them. The first of these Faults, to wit, his mingling the Actors and Spectators Concerns, he is several times guilty of in other Plays, and when it is not by way of Prologue neither; but the latter, he is guilty of no where but in his Prologue to Poenulus, that I remember.

Pag. 22. l. 12. My Father's so tender of Alcmena.] Alcumena hujus honoris gratiâ, pater curavit. As Madam Dacier observes, this Tenderness is in respect of her Health and Body, and not of her Reputation, as the Word Honoris seem to imply.

div.head: Scene the Third.
div.p: Pag. 23. l. 1. Take care o' the bringing up the Child.] Verùm quod erit natum, tollito. It seems very odd to us, that Iupiter shou'd leave such an impertinent useless Command with Alcmena; but in those days nothing was more common, than the exposing of their Children, so that this Order was very proper at that time; and the Word Tollito alludes to that very Custom.

Ibid. l. 14. If your Lady shou'd find out the Cheat.] Illa si istis rebus te •… sciat operam dare. It is a great doubt among the Interpreters, whether this Illa means Iano or Alcmena; therefore I have done it in as general Terms as my Author has.

div.head: Scene the Fifth.
div.p: Pag. 25. l. 8. This has been a longer night than ordinary.] Many Learned Men have mistaken this long Night for that of Hercules's Begetting, and so have thought this Play had continued nine or ten Months; whereas this, most evidently, is that immediately before his Birth; our Poet not going according to the common Fable, as they suppos'd he did.

div.head: ACT II.
div.p: THE first Interval is fill'd up with Socia's returning to the Port, to tell his Master Amphitryon all the strange Things he had seen.

div.head: Scene the First.
div.p: It ought to be observ'd, that the whole time of this Scene's acting, Amphitryon, Socia, and the Prisoners, are moving towards the Front of the Stage, and Amphitryon's Door; which may well enough be, considering the Vastness of the Roman Stage, being 180 Foot in the Front. This Scene cannot be represented with nigh the Probability upon our small Stage.

Pag. 28. l. 23. The Fellow's bewitch'd, and fallen into some ill hands.] Huic homini nescio quid est mali malâ objectum man •… . Our Phrase, Ill Hands, has the same meaning that Malâ manu has here, which signifies those of Witches, or Sorcerers; therefore Socia's Jest, immediately following, is as effectual in the Translation as in the Original. I added the Word Bewitch'd, to make it still more clear.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p: Pag. 31. l. 16, &c. Why there's your Lady has din'd, by her Belly. Amp. 'Po, Blockhead, I left her wi' Child when I went to the Campaign.] I am apt to believe, that this Jest of Socia's wou'd scarcely pass Muster upon our Theatre, tho' in a Farce; yet still it serves to keep up the Character, and carry on the Humour of a mean Slave, such as Socia was. But what is most remarkable, is, that this insipid Jest shou'd be a Preparation to the Main Incident, and there is but one more in the whole Comedy, except in the Prologue, which in reality is no part of a Play. If the Matter of a Preparation be ridiculous, it is oftentimes the Poet's Art and Cunning, tho' I know not whether I may say it 〈◊〉 so here.

Pag. 33. l. 34, &c. Yes, Madam, there are Fruits too, of •… ying-in Women, and Fruits too, to strengthen their Hearts, and keep 'em from Swooning.] Enimverò pregnanti oportet & malum, & malum dari, ut quod obrodat sit, animo si malè esse occaeperit. The Wit (or whatever the Reader please to call it) of this Passage, consists in Socia's playing upon the ambiguous Word Malum, which Alcmena had spoken just before; and this signifies either a Mischief, or an Apple; therefore nothing, that I know of, in our Language, cou'd answer it so well as Fruits, which may be taken in either good or bad Sense.

div.head: Scene the Fourth.
div.p: Pag. 38. l. 5. You complain'd o' Drowsiness.] This is the middle of a remarkable Narration, which is, by pieces, scatter'd through this and the Second Scene. The Poet ingeniously contrives here, to tell the Spectators of many considerable Matters, and yet, all the time, seems to have no manner of Design for any such thing, but a quite different one. This sort of Address is always to be admired, and as much to be imitated.

Ibid. l. 21. A very pretty Business; if she has taken away his Manhood, and made him a Lady.] Haeret haec res: siquidem haec jam mulier facta •… st ex viro. This is right Socia again, playing upon the Word Vir, which Amphitryon had just upbraided his Wife with, signifying both Husband, and Man. Here, by luck, the Word Lord has preserv'd the Jest as well.

Ibid. l. 13. I ne •… re gave t'any Man but you, the least Liberty, &c.] Ut mî extra unum te mortalis nemo corpus corpore contigit. If Plautus has made Alcmena speak here according to her high Quality, as I doubt not but he has; it plainly appears, that our way of expressing Things in this nature, is more modest, clean, and genteel, than theirs usually was.

div.head: ACT III.
div.p: THE second Interval is fill'd up with Amphitryon's going to search for Naucrates.

div.head: Scene the First.
div.p: This Scene is still but a part of the Prologue; and tho' it be a great Fault to confound the Spectators Concerns with the Theatral-Action, and such as cannot be vindicated; yet at the same time, it ought not to be forgotten, that the Prologue is never any part of the Play, as I observ'd before.

Pag. 41. l. 3. My Lodgings are i' th' upper Garret.] In superiore •… ui habito coenaculo. If this Passage be consider'd as spoken immediately to the Spectators, it is very comical; for whether he be look'd upon as real Iupiter, or as a poor Player and Slave, whose Lodgings were always in the Garret, it agrees exactly with him. But this is almost lost in our Tongue, even tho' a better Word than Garret were us'd.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p: Ibid. l. penult. &c. The House is grown odious to me now, since my Lord accuses me o' Dishonesty, Shame, and Infamy.] The Poet had a very great Occasion for Alcmena's appearing at this time, both for the Reconciliation, and the notable Consequences thereof: But see what an ingenious Pretext he finds for her coming there at that time; as likewise he has, at the two other times she appears, when both the Hour and Place might have made it very improbable for a Woman of her Rank and Quality. Whenever this Rule is not observ'd in a Play, nothing seems more forc'd and unnatural, nothing more botch'd and bungl'd.

Pag. 43. l. 9, 10. Let me beg, and intreat ye, to forgive,
forget, and be pacify'd.] Oro, obsecro, da mihi hoc veniam, ignosce, irata ne sies. This Place, among many others, may be an Instance of my binding my self so scrupulously to my Author's Words, even when they have just the same Signification, which often makes a Translation the worse, as, perhaps, in this place. But whenever such be made to run well, it does not only show the Translator's Skill, and the Copiousness of our Words or Expressions, but likewise is very useful to teach young Scholars both Languages at once.

Ibid. l. 13, 14. Farewel, keep your own Things, and let me ha' mine.] Valeas, tibi habeas res tuas, re •… das mea •… . This was the constant Form of Words us'd at a Divorc •… , and consequently the Beauty of it must be lost in our Language.

Pag. 44. l. 3, &c. I must send for Blepharon, our Ships Pilot, t'invite him to Dinner.—But not a mouthful shall Socia get; and here'll be rare sport when I come to grapple with Amphitryon.] Iupiter's sending for Blepharon, was an excellent Preparation of the Poet's, to cause all that Sport which happen'd in the Fourth Act, and to bring about the Catastrophe more dextrously; but still he took care to have a fair Pretence for so doing. His foretelling something of this sport, in another place, wou'd have been a Fault, but here it serves purely to raise the Audiences Expectations; and nothing makes a Play succeed better than doing of that well.

div.head: Scene the Fifth.
div.p: Pag. 45. l. ult. The mean time I'm sacrificing to my self.] Here ends the Third Act, which is contrary to all the common Books, which make it end a Scene after. Here is a manifest Cessation of Action upon the Stage, when in the other there is none.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.p: THE third Interval is fill'd up with Amphitryon's looking for Naucrates, Socia's for Blepharon, and with Iupiter's and Alcmena's Sacrificing.

div.head: Scene the First.
div.p: The greatest part of this Scene, makes the last Part of the Prologue, or at least, it is so much of that Nature as properly enough to be call'd by that Name, though it be not placed before the Play, as the Word Prologue, in the most strict Sense, implies.

Pag. 46. l. 7, &c. Their vast haste, is only for a Vessel safely arriv'd, an old Fellow upo' the Fret, or so.] This, and a Line or two before, was design'd by Plautus for a Satyr upon some of the Play-Wrights of his time, whose chiefest Beauties, it seems, consisted in a Slave's running in vast haste with some such News as before mention'd, and throwing down all he meets; so making the Spectators laugh by such means, when they cou'd not by better.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p: In this little Scene, there is a great deal of Art of the Poet, by making Amphitryon so particularly tell the several places he had been at, to look for Naucrates; for if it had been otherwise, the Spectators might all have wonder'd that Socia did not meet him, since he was gone but a little before to the same place; and their Meeting wou'd have spoil'd the whole Plot. This is an excellent Instance of the exact Probability that the Ancients observ'd; and what is still remarkable, is, that tho' at another time it wou'd have been undecent, and unlikely for a Man of his Quality to look himself at so many places, yet now it was highly probable, since he was so extreamly overcome with Rage and Jealousie.

div.head: Scene the Third.
div.p: Pag. 48. l. 21. Thou cursed branded Rogue.] Ulmorum acheruns. That is to say, One whose Back had consum'd as much Brush-Wood as Hell cou'd. A Verbal Translation, in this place, wou'd have sounded wretchedly. Perhaps, Thou Plague to the Whipping-Post, might have done as well as any.

Ibid. l. antepenult. &c. Then I shall sacrifice—Amp. What? Me •… . Something to your Worship's Pate.] Sacrifico tibi. Am. Qui? Me. Quia enim te macto infortunio. The Jest of this Passage consists in Mercury's playing so comically upon the Word Macto, which is a proper Term us'd in Sacrificing, and, in that place, the same with Magis aucto, and Augeo; and whereas it is usually join'd to Honore, and the like, he merrily joins it to Infortunio, as it is in Terence's Phormio. This cannot be preserv'd in our Tongue; yet this Translation does in a great measure answer the Design.
