Pag. 49. l. 1. You, Iail-bird?] Tun' me mactes, carnufex? All from this, to nigh the End of this Act, is generally suppos'd to have been done by another hand; but whether it be so or no, I shall not offer to determine. However, it is undoubtedly very ancient, and the Plot and Incidents as well carry'd on as Plautus himself cou'd have done; and I believe that those Persons who seem able to prove it not his by the difference in Stile, will be less able to do it by the difference in Spirit and Genius.

Ibid. l. 20. Y' ought to get your Brains clear'd.] Bacchanal te exercuisse oportuit. This is spoken in Reference to Drunkenness, or rather indeed Madness, which Mercury lays to Amphitryon's Charge; and therefore the Word Bacchus, about 18 Verses after, in that place, seems properly enough translated, T •… m-a-Bedlam.

div.head: Scene the Fifth.
div.p: It is pleasant to observe how naturally the Comical Incidents in this Scene, spring from their Preparations in the second and third Scenes of the third Act.

Pag. 51. l. 19. But why do I mention Foreign Prodigies, &c.] All this Monologue is of a right Tragical Strain; the Passion truly just and natural; and the Thought as ingenious and moral. It seems to be writ exactly with the same Spirit as that Monologue in the beginning of the Second Scene of the Second Act.

div.head: Scene the Sixth.
div.p: Pag. 55. l. 11, &c. Nothing goes well wi' me to day. I left Blepharon and Socia, to hunt up my Cozen Naucrates; him I can't find high nor low, and t'other two I ve quite lost.] Many have mistaken the Design of this Place, and have thought it was spoken by Amphitryon, or that something had been left out; whereas Iupiter speaks this only to puzzle and confound Amphitryon, Blepharon, and Socia, and so carry on his Design the better.

div.head: Scene the Seventh.
div.p: Pag. 56. l. 17. For that Affront, I'll throatle ye.] It may seem very indecent for Iupiter and Amphitryon to scuffle at this rate, and not rather to have drawn their Swords; but this agrees exactly with that Character which Mercury in the Prologue gives of this Play, when he calls it Tragi Comedy. Besides, drawing of Swords might have prov'd too Tragical.

Pag. 57. l. 15. Because if our Army were routed, I might secure m' own Retreat.] The Application of this Passage is very Satyrical, considering this Play was acted before the Romans, whose Generals were never us'd to practise such ways. The Sharpness of the Reflection is considerably lost upon our Stages.
Pag. 58. l. 22. And I can go no further*.] Quid agam nescio. Here ends all that which goes by the Name of Supposititious.

div.head: ACT V.
div.p: THE fourth Interval is fill'd by Amphitryon's being in a Swoon upon the Stage, and Alcmena's Labour. This Interval is very peculiar; and I don't know another Instance of this nature among the Ancients, but in the Hecuba of Euripides: So that an Act is finish'd whenever the Stage is without Action, whether there be an Actor there or no.

div.head: Scene the First.
div.p: Pag. 59. l. ult. Mercy upo' me! What shall I do? I've seen so many Prodigies within.] The Poet had a particular Occasion for Bromia's appearing at this time; therefore he has found a very fair Pretext for bringing of her there, to wit, the great Fright she was in within Doors, which Reason she more particularly alledges in the next Scene.

Pag. 60. l. 6, &c. What Voices and Noises, what Clashes and Flashes? How suddenly, how frequently, how terribly it thunder'd!] Strepitus, crepitus, sonitus, tonitrus; ut subi •… , ut properè, ut validè tonuit? It seems, among the Ancients, whene'er Iupiter appear'd like a God, it was always with Thunder and Lightning. Since this is a sort of a rumbling Passage in the Original, I have also made it so in my Translation.

Ibid. l. 24. My Lord!] Here ends the first Scene. Now if any shou'd blame me for making a Distinction of Scenes when the same Persons are still upon the Stage; I reply, That the very same Thing that made the Distinction of Acts, as Amphitryon's Condition did, must undoubtedly make the Distinction of Scenes.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p: Pag. 61. l. 16. First, you must know, she's brought to bed o' two Boys.] This is the Beginning of a pleasant and lively Narration, which is attended with all its due Circumstances; to wit, the Place as well as the Party proper for the Relation; the Person necessary to hear it; and, above all, the Design of relating it, which was, The Vindication of Alcmena's Honour. All these Circumstances are not only to make it probable, but also to keep the Spectators from supposing it made for their Information; which, tho' it is the principal Design of all Narrations, yet nothing ought more industriously to be conceal'd from them, than such a Design.

div.head: Scene the Fourth.
div.p: Iupiter's descending here, agrees exactly with Horace's Rule, Nec Deus intersit, nisi dignus vindice nodus inciderit. For a God cou'd never come upon a better Design, or in a better Time, to satisfie either Amphitryon, or the Spectators.

div.head: Scene the Fifth.
div.p: Pag. 64. l. 4. And great Jove's Cause.] Iovis summi causa. The Romans believ'd that this Play made much for the Honour of Iupiter; therefore, afterwards, it was commonly Acted in Times of publick Troubles and Calamities, to appease his Anger.

div.trailer: The End of the Remarks upon Amphitryon.

div.p: EPIDICUS.

div.head: Dramatis Personae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Periphanes, an old Rich Gentleman of Athens, and Father to Stratippocles.
Apecides, Another old Gentleman, his Neighbour.
Stratipocles, A Young Gentleman, Son to Periphanes, and belonging to the Army.
Cheribulus, Another Young Gentleman, his Friend and Companion.
Epi •… cus, The cunning Servant to Periphanes, and Stratippocles.
Thesprion, Armour-Bearer to Stratipocles.
A Captain, Of Rhodes, a Braggadocio.
A Banker, Of Thebes, of whom Stratippocles had taken •… p M •… ny.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Philippa, A Woman of Epidaurus, kept by Periphanes in her young Days.
Thelestis, Belov'd by Statippocles, who buys •… er at the Camp.
•… polistis, A Musick-Girl, belov'd by Stratippocles, and by him set free in his Absence.
A Musick-Woman, that passes for Stratippocles's Mistress.

list.head: MUTES.
list.item: Servants,
Attendants, &c.

div.p: SCENE, Athens, in the Street. On one Side of the Stage, stands Periphanes's and Apecides's Houses; on the other, Cheribulus's House.
TIME, About Five or Six Hours, beginning at Six or Seven a Clock in the Morning.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Thesprion, wrapt up in his Cloak, in great haste; and immediately after, Epidicus, who catches hold of him.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: STay, young Man.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Who's that puls me by the Cloak, when I'm in such haste.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: So it seems. But you're a plaguy impertinent one.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Open your Eyes, Thesprion.

sp.speaker: Thes. turning about]
sp.p: Bless me! Epidicus, is't you?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You may trust your Eyes for once.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: O, good morrow t'ye.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And a good Day to you. Well-come home with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Well, and what next?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why next, Boy, I'll present ye with a Treat, according to th'usual Custom.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Upon Honour then—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: —I'll accept of't, if you do.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Well but how d'ye? How fares your Corps?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: My Face is a Sample o'that.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Now I have ye, rare Rogue! thou'rt got to be fatter, and in better plight than ever.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Ay, Thanks to this thriving Hand— holding up his Hand.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: —Which ought t'ha' been cut off long since.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Pshaw, I'm grown more honest than formerly.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Because I steal more openly.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A duce on ye, for setting such plaguy large Strides. As soon as I laid Eye on ye at the Port, I ran like a Race-Horse, but cou'd n't come up wi'ye for my Guts, till now.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Po, you're a puny Town-Chitterlin.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You're a hectoring Camp-Bully, I know.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: 'Tis a little scurrilous, but speak your Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ha'ye been well e're since you went, what say ye?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Off and on—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: —The Wooden Horse, you mean. O, I hate that damn'd Variety most mortally.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Why, I told ye nothing but Truth.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Come, answer me me sincerely.—What's become of our Master's Son? How does he do?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Lusty, and strong as Hercules.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Now you've told me the joyfullest News i'the World: But where is he?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: He came along wi'me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: How so? unless you brought him home i'your Knapsack, or else in your Pocket.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: O hang ye.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Or you:—I must examine you; hear me, and you shall be heard i'your turn.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: The very Words of a Judge, in truth.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: It becomes my Gravity.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: You don't pretend to be Lord Chief Iustice, d'ye?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why, d'ye know a more honourable Person in Town than I?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: But, Old Boy, you want one Accoutrement to your Office.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Prethee what's that?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Your Beadles, with their Staffs for your Honour's Pate.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You're a damn'd Rogue.—But what's your Answer?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: To what Question, pray?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What's become o'my Master Stratippocles's Arms?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Faith, faln into th' Enemy's Hands.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: His Arms?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: They went away with a Whip.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Don't ye banter now?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Troth, I'm in earnest. They have 'em in possession.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Mary, 'twas a plaguy Business.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Po, Achilles, and others ha'done the same before him. I'll warrant ye 'twill redound to his Honour.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: As how, I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: For following such noble Examples.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Troth, I believe Vulcan made his Arms for him; they were so plaguy quick in going over to th'Enemy. If our Son o'Thetis has lost his, the kind Nereads will bring him more. But then he must be sure to supply th'Armorers wi'Stuff and Materials, if e'r he hopes to be plunder'd every Campaign.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Come, adone wi'this Discourse.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: That's as your Worship pleases.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Leave impertinant Questions.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But tell me, where's my Master Stratippocles?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: There's a certain reason why he daren't come wi'me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Prethee what is't?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: He has no desire to be seen of his Father.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p:
I'll tell ye.—He has brought out o'the Plunder,
a young Captive Lass, fair and sprightly, who seems of a good Family.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: The same that comes from my Mouth,

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What did he buy her for?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Because he had a mind to her.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And how many Minds has this Creature got? I'm sure, before he went to the Campaign, he left me in charge to buy him a Musick-Girl, he lov'd, of a certain Slave-Merchant, and I've executed his Orders.—

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Just as the Wind blows, my Friend, so you must furl your Sails.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Alas! I'm broke all in pieces!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: How; why so?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But—what did this Lass cost?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Little enough.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: That's none o'my Question.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: How many Pounds?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: So many [Holding up his Fingers.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What, a hundred Pounds?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Which he took up of a Banker at Thebes, and gives him above a Groat i'the Pound Interest for every Day he has it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Lamentable!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: The Banker's come over with him, and demands the Mony.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Bless me? I'm ruin'd to the Devil and all.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: How so? What's the matter, my Friend?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: He has lost me.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Who has.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: The Gentleman who lost his Arms.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: But why so?

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.p: Why, he was continually dunning me wi' Letters from th'Army, to— [Aside] But mum for that. 'Tis better for a Slave to set his Ears on work, than his Tongue; that's the wisest course by half.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Troth, I can't imagine why you tremble so. Poor Epidicus, thou'rt in a sad pickle: guilty o' some damnable bus'ness i'my Absence, and thy very looks betray thee.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Prethee, don't tease me so.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: I'll be gone then.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Stay, you shan't go yet. [He holds him.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Why, not yet?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But is he really in love with the Girl he bought?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: A pretty Question!—up to the Ears, Man.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Then my poor Back must smart for't.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: He loves her better than ever he did you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And let the Devil love you.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p:
Prethee leave that subject,—He charg'd me not to go home to his Fathers, but directly to Cherib •…
lus's here, till he came there himself.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Because he wou'd n't so much as meet, or see his Father, till he had clear'd all with his Banker.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: This is Hell upon Earth!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Now let me go and meet him.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What will th'old Man say, when he comes to know o'this? However, let's fall nobly, with our Swords in our Hands.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Fall how you please, what's that to me?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'll not fall singly; I shall desire the same Civility o'you too, as one Friend wou'd of another.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Wou'd Old Nick had you and your Projects too.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Go then, if you be in such plaguy haste.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: If it be so, I ne'r met with a more easie parting. [Exit Thesprion.

He's gone, and now thou'rt alone: thou seest in what a sweet Condition thou'rt in, Mr. Epidicus; and without speedy Relief, thou'rt undoubtedly blown up. So many tottering Ruins, and such vast Loads o' Mischiefs come tumbling upo' my •… ead, that 'tis impossible to subsist without a thousand Props. And yet I can't find one to help to sustain this confounded Shock.—What a Rogue was I t'impose upo'th' Old Man wi'my damn'd Tricks, and make him believe he had redeem'd his Daughter, when 'twas only a Musick-Girl, his Son's Miss, whom he order'd to buy when he went to the Camp. But now my Gentleman, to please his Humour, has pick'd up another there, and my Skin must pay the purchase: For when our old Fox comes once to smell out the Roguery, I shall be flea'd alive. Therefore have all your Wits about ye.—Projecting's to no purpose; for my Brains are all Confusion.— [He looks upon himself] Epidicus, thou'rt an errant Ass.— [In another Tone] But why so scurrilous, my Friend!—Because, Fool, thou'st left thy self to the wide Word.—Why, what wou'd y' ha' me do?—Why that Question to me?—Because formerly y' use to be so plaguy cunning at advising.—What?—What, I say?—I must to work upon something.—But I'm too backward in meeting my Gentleman, to know how matters stand.— [Discovering Stratippocles and Cheribulus] O here he comes, i'the dumps too, with his Friend Cheribulus.—I'll move on one side, to hear their Discourse wi'more ease. [He stands on one side a little.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Stratippocles and Cheribulus, at another part of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Thus I've told ye the whole Story, Cheribulus; and given ye a full Account o' my Troubles and Love.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Sure, Stratippocles, thour't very childish for one o' thy Age and Courage. What, asham'd o' thy Bargan, Man, when she's one of a good Family? Who a duce can blame thee for this?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: All those who envy'd me, ha' declared themselves m' Enemies upo' this Account; tho' truly to her Chastity, I ne'r offer'd the least Violence or Incivility.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: This is a Vertue, in my Opinion, a degree above any common moderation in Love.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Po, Words will give no ease to a Man in pain: He's the Friend, whose Actions supply one in a puzling Case, and at a pinch.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: How wou'd y' ha' me help ye?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: By lending me a hundred Pounds, to pay off the Banker I had it of.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Really if I had it, you shou'dn't ask me twice.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: What am I the better, when your Liberality lies wholly in Words, and nothing at all in Deed •… .

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Why, Faith, every day I'm teaz'd, and worried to death with a parcel o' Duns.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I'de sooner see such Friends starve in Prison than live in a Palace.—Well, I must borrow Epidicus's help, tho' I pay dearly for th' use of 't; but I shall send him to Bridewel with his Skin stript o're his Ears, if he doesn't procure the hundred Pounds as soon as the last Word's pronounc'd.

sp.speaker: Epi. aside.]
sp.p:
I'm in a hopeful Condition: He promises well, and I don't question his performance i' the
least. So then, my Back shall be nobly treated, and all at free Cost.—I'll e'n board 'em.— [Goes to them.] My dear Master, no Man's more joyful at your safe Arrival than your humble Servant Epidicus.

sp.speaker: Stra. turning about]
sp.p: Where's he?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Here, Sir—I'm glad to see you well in Town agen.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I don't question but y'are, as much as my self.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Have ye been well all this time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: In Body, but not in Mind.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I perform'd my Duty, and observ'd your Commands, to a tittle. I've bought up the Girl you sent so many Letters about.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: You've lost your Labour i' that.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Lost, how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Because at present, she neither charms, nor pleases me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Then what occasion was there for so many repeated Commands, and Letters?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I lov'd her then, but now my Heart's otherwise ingag'd.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Faith 'tis very hard, t'have one's Services so ill rewarded. My best Endeavours are turn'd against me, by the fickleness o' your Passion.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I wasn't Compos mentis, when I writ those Letters.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Must I attone for your crazy Tricks; and my Back pay the price o' your Indiscretion?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: What's all this prating? I've occasion for a hundred Pounds down o' the Nail, which must be paid to the Banker with all Expedition.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Pray, where shall I ha't? Of what Banker shou'd I take it up?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Where you please. But if I ha'n't the Mony before Sunset, ne'r expect to see home agen, but strait to Bridewell you go.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You, Sir, can talk o' these things unmov'd, without dread or danger. I'm right sensible o' m' Executioners, and the pain of a good Beating.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: How then? Wou'd you see your Master make way with himself?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Not so neither.—I'll first run the hazard, as bold as it is.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Now I like ye: Thour't a brave Fellow introth.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'm resolv'd t' undergo what you'd ha' me.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: What will ye do with the Musick-Girl you bought then?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye, I'll ha' some Invention, some Expedient, or some Trick to save all at last.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Faith thous't a fruitful Noddle, to my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I know a rich Euboan Captain, with Mony at Command, who when he comes to know o' your buying of this, and your bringing home th' other, he'll earn estly be at ye, to take her off your Hands.—But where's the Girl you brought wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: She shall be forth-coming.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: What stay we here for?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Let's to yours, and there make a jolly Day on't. [Exeunt Stratippocles and Cheribulus.

Go in. The mean time, in these Brains must I have a Committee o' the whole House, to consider of Ways and Means for the raising o' Supplies to carry on this vigorous War.—Well, Friend Epidicus, look well to thy hits; for this is a plaguy sudden Bus'ness. The De'el a bit o' time's here for dozing, or delaying; for
a swinging Battery must be rais'd against th' old Mans Pockets.—In then, Epidicus, and keep thy young Master from stragling here, least his old Father shou'd chance to snap him up. [Exit Epidicus after them.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Ape. entring.
sp.p: TIs a common failing in most People, t' use Modesty when there's no occasion for't; and when there's most of all, they lay't aside. What need ye be asham'd o' marrying one of a good Family, tho' of mean Fortune; especially one, as you believe, you had your Daughter by, that's now at home?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I dread my Son's Reproaches.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Edod, I thought the Remembrance o' your last Wife, had frighted you from Matrimony; for you ne'r can look upon her Grave, but y' offer Thanks for her Departure: And truly you've reason, since y' had the good luck t'out-live that cross Piece.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: O, I was a second Hercules i' the time of her Reign. His Combate with the Amazonian Queen, was nothing to what I endured.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Troth, the Mony did well however.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ay marry, if I cou'd ha' had it alone.

sp.speaker: Epi. to Stratippocles and Cheribulus within.]
sp.p: St' St'! Silence! Courage, my Lads. Nothing but signs o' good luck. Then I've a plaguy sharp Lancet to breath the best Vein i'th' old Man's Purse.— [Coming from the Door.] O yonder's he.—Both th' old Bubles as I could wish, before Apecides's Door. Now will I turn Horse-leech, and suck out the Hearts Blood o' these old Fools, who pass for the prime Pillars o' the State.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Marry him as soon as you can.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I like your Advice.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: I heard he was intangl'd with a Musick-Girl, but who I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ay, that goes to the Heart o' me.

sp.speaker: Epi. overhearing them.]
sp.p: In good Faith, I've th' Assistance, Bounty and Love of all the Gods. For th' old Men ha' now open'd a Passage for my Tricks to make Incursions, and snub 'em o' their Mony.—About it then, Friend Epidicus, wrap thy short Cloak about thee, and pretend t'ha' been looking the whole Town for th' old Man: Do all with a jerk.— [He throws his Cloak about him, and seems in vast haste.] Bless my Soul! what wou'd I give to meet wi' my Master Peraphanes at home. I'm tyr'd off my Legs, wi' searching all the Town over for him, at the Surgeons, the Barbers, the Race-Ground, the Market, the Perfumers, the Armorers, and all the Bankers i' the Town.—I'm quite hoarse with asking, and was nigh breaking my Neck a hundred times for haste.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Who calls Epidicus? [Surlily.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'm Periphanes.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: And I, Apecides.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And, troth, I'm Epidicus.—O, Sir, I've met ye both i' the best time i' the World.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Hold.—Pray give me a little time to breath in—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, take time then.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: O my Heart!—Let me take breath—

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Come, rest your self.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Now observe.—All the Troops that were marching to Thebes, are discharg'd, and sent home.—

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I affirm it to be true.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: On your own Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How came you to know't?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Because I saw the Streets as full o' Soldiers as they cou'd pack, with all the Arms, and Horses.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is extreordinary indeed.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Then they had a mort o' Prisoners, with Boys and Girls, some two, some three, and others five a piece. The People they all came thronging about 'em; every Body crowding to see their own Sons.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I faith, nothing cou'd be better.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Then I believe the whole Corporation o' Courtizans i' the City came in all i' their Finery, to meet their Gallants, and charm 'em with their presence: And, what was most observable, a great many of 'em wore Nets under their Scarfs. When I had got to the Haven, there I found her, attended by four several Musitians playing—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Who, Epidicus?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: She who your Son so many Years lov'd, and dy'd for; and is in a fair way to ruin his Riches and Reputation, his own self, and your Worship's self. She stood waiting for him at the Haven.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Damn'd Jilt!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: She was richly dress'd in her gold Lace, so neatly! so trimly! so modish!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How a duce was she dress'd then? With a Cloak, or a Robe, or had she a Milliner's Shop upon her back? There's variety enough.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A Woman carry a whole Shop upon her back?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where's the Wonder? You may daily meet these Creatures i' the Streets with Houses and Lands upo' their backs. When their Sparks are assess'd for the Taxes, they've no Mony; but freely pay their Contributions when they're tax'd by their Whores. What a confounded Jargon o' names do these Jades rake up every Year for their Habits? There's your light Mant plated, your Stiff-bodied-Gown, your Loose-Gown, your Night-Gown, your Riding-Gown, your Imbroider'd, and Speckl'd Gowns, Pane'd Works, and Plum'd Works, Petticoats, Hoods, Scarfs, Tours and Top-knots, Fingle-Fangles, and Gold-Bobs, with all the Colours o' the Rainbow, and Figures of all the Flowers, Birds, Beasts, Fishes, Flies, and Monsters, i'th' Universe. Nay some o' their Dresses make 'em look like Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What are those, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your damn'd Night-Rails.—This plaguy Catalogue o' Names, often make their poor Cullies Pockets smoak for't.—But on wi' your Story.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: There stood two Women behind me, discoursing to themselves; upo' which, I gave way a little, and made as tho' I took no notice o' what they said. I cou'dn't hear every word perfectly, yet I'm sure I can't be mistaken i' the main.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'd fain know what it was.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Said one o' these Women to th' other,—

sp.speaker: Per, interrupting]
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
Patience, Sir, and you'll hear all.—After they had cast their Eyes upo' your Son's Mistress. Good now, said one, What strange luck has this Creature,
t'have her Gallant immediately pay her Ransom? Her Gallant, said th' other, why who's he? At that she nam'd young Stratippocles. rich Periphanes's Son.

sp.speaker: Per. aside.]
sp.p: As I live, I must run my Country.— [To Epidicus] but what's this you tell me?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nothing but the truth, Sir.—Upon hearing o' this Discourse, I began to creep nigher, and nigher to 'em, by degrees, as tho' I had been forc'd that way by the crowd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But, said th' other agen, how know ye this? Who told ye so? Why, said she, there came a Letter to day from Stratippocles to her, to let her know he had taken up the Mony of a Banker at Thebes, had it in his Hands, and was bringing it home for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: So then.—All's lost. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: She said, she had it from her own Mouth, and saw the Letter.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How shall I do i' this case? I must ha' your advice, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: We must find out some effectual, and cunning Expedient; for, troth, I verily believe, he'll be here shortly, if he ben't already.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Might I presume, t' instruct ye, I'd shew ye such a clever way as you'd both approve of, or I'm much mistaken.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And what's that, honest Epidicus!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And you'll say 'tis pat for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Why d'ye keep us in suspence then?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Because you, who are wisest, ought to be heard first; I, afterwards.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Po, let's hear't.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, you'll laugh at me. [Fawningly.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Faith, but we won't.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: If ye like this Project, you may follow't; if not, another may be sought for. For my part, I'm neither Inventor, nor Promoter of't, any further than to serve you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I thank ye for that—Prithee let's hear your Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: 'Tis to chuse a Wife for your Son immediately, and take a swinging Revenge upo' this Musick-Wench he's now upon freeing, and so strangely debauches him: Then t' order Matters so as to make her a Slave as long as he lives.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: That's right as can be.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'd do any thing to have it speedily brought about.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why, truly, now's the time to do't, before he comes home: 'Twill be to Morrow before he comes to Town, and not to day.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How know ye that?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Very well, Sir. I saw one that came from him, who said he wou'd be here to Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, but go on: What must we do next?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: This is my Opinion; that you ransom this Musick-Girl, as tho' you had a mind to her, and was mightily stricken with her your self.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And what of all that?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What? You may buy her out o' your Son's Hands, before he returns, and pretend 'tis to give her her Freedom.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, I understand ye.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: When you've once got her into your Hands, you may remove her t' any by Place from the City, if you think it so convenient.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'm clearly o' that mind.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What say you, Sir! [To Apecides.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: What shou'd I? 'Tis a notable cunning Contrivance, I think.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: By this means, you'll cut off all your Sons hopes o' marrying her; and bring him to compliance at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Thour't a cunning Rogue, and pleasest me strangely.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Sir, what you're about, requires expedition.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Very true, indeed.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I've a Trick too, that the Merchant shan't smell your Designs.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Let's hear't.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: So you shall.—Observe.

sp.speaker: Ape. Aside to Periphanes.]
sp.p: This is the craftiest Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'm affraid we shall want one to pay the Mony for this Wench. For 'twon't be so convenient for you to go your self.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Lest the Merchant suspect you buy her upo' your Sons account,—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Very right.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: —To hinder him of his Mistress; and so his Suspicions may chance to cross your Designs.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where shall we find one proper to manage this Business?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: This Gentleman is the fittest i'the World. He understands a Bargain to a Tittle, and has the Law at his Fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Epidicus, I gi' ye Thanks.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And I'll endeavour to deserve 'em: I'll find out the Master o' the Musick-Girl, carry the Mony with the Gentleman, and bring her to ye.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What's the lowest price of her?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: The lowest price? Perhaps you may get her for a hundred Pounds. But if you send too much, it shall be return'd faithfully. There can be no Cheat in't; and your Mony won't lye dead ten days, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
Because there's another young Spark has a Months mind to this Wench, a Rhodian Captain, vastly rich, a stout Soldier, a terrible Fellow, and a grand Braggadocio. He'll certainly take her off your Hands, and pay ye ready Mony with all his Heart. Do but
venture upon her, and you may gain the Lord knows what by the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Heavens grant I may.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Don't question it.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Will you go in, Sir, and bring out the Mony? I'll away to the Piazza; and be sure, Epidicus, do you meet me there.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Don't ye go from thence, before I come.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: I'll stay for ye there.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Come in, Epidicus.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Go in, Sir, and draw over your Mony, I shan't make 'ye stay. [Exeunt Apecides and Periphanes severally.

Hang me, if I believe there's e'r a piece o' Ground in all our Country yields half so well as this old Fellows Bags. For tho' they be ne'r so well secur'd and seal'd up, sweep says my Worship with as much Mony as he pleases. But, Faith, I've a plaguy Scruple that th' old Man shou'd find out the Roguery on't, and stick as close to my Back as an old Rook to a rich Cully. One thing puts me to my last Trumps; that is, to know which Musick-Girl I had best shew Apecides.—O I ha't i' my Head.—Th' old Man order'd me this Morning to find up a Musick-Girl to sing for him at his Sacrifice. I'll soon produce one, and teach her her Lesson, how to carry on the Cheat handsomly t' our old Gentleman.—Now I'll in, and receive the Mony o' this old silly Put. [Exit Epidicus.

div.trailer: The end of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Stratip. entring]
sp.p: S Death, I'm torn asunder, and eaten up with th'Expectation of all Epidicus's fine Promises.—It torments me strangely; and I'd gi' the World to know whether there be any Hopes or not.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: For all Epidicus's great Helps, y'ought to seek out elswhere: For I could ha' told ye before-hand, you weren't to expect any thing from his Brain.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I'm a miserable Man, in earnest.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: 'Tis childish i'you, to vex your self so.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: As I'm a living Soul, if I once lay hands on him, 'tshall ne'r be said that a pitiful Slave abus'd his Master without Punishment.—But what wou'd ye have him do, who has no Mony; when you, who has so much at command, won't part with a Penny, to keep a Friend from sinking?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Upo' my Word, if I had it, I wou'd with all my Heart. However you needn't fear, but you'll meet wi' something, by some ways, some means, from some Place, or from some Body; and you've still some hopes o'sharing i'my good Fortune, when I meet with't my self.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Po, hang such sneaking Fellows.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: What's your Fancy in giving me this Language?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p:
Because your Tongue ran all upo' your silly somethings, your some means, your some Places, and your some Bodies, which are all nothing to the purpose. I'll
not weary out m'ears any longer wi'this Stuff; nor expect any more Help from ye, than from one that's ne'r thought of. [Angrily.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Epidicus on the other side of the Stage, with a Bag of Mony.

sp.speaker: Epi. to Periphanes, within.]
sp.p: Well, Sir, you've perform'd your Part; now must I mine. After this care's over, you may set your Heart at rest.— [He comes from the Door] Condemn'd every Cross; and no hopes of a Reprieve.— [He takes some of it out] Faith, 'thas a plaguy alluring Eye.—Trust m'agen, old Fool; 'tis an ancient Trick entail'd upon our Family.—Gods! what a glorious, prosperous, and lucky Day was this? But I'm plaguy backwards in carrying this rich Prize into Harbour, Delays are very dangerous i'this case.—But what's yonder? the two Sparks, my Master, and Cheribulus.—Well, what now?—Here, Sir, take it, if you like it. [To Stratippocles.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: How much is there? [He takes it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Enough, and more than enough; something over-plus. I've got above twenty Guinea's more than you owe to your Banker. You see, Sir, as long as I can please, and oblige you, I'm sufficiently prodigal o' m'own Back.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Your Back, why so?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: By making your Father guilty o'Bag-slaughter.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: What a duce is that?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
Nay, I don't mind your old and common Phrase, Hold up his Hand at the Bar, but I make him hold up his Hand at the Bags. For I've already paid off the Slave-Merchant, wi' m' own Hands, for that Girl who goes for your Sister, Now I've hit upon a way, to put another
Trick upo' your Father, and do you a good turn into the Bargain. I had this Discourse wi •… th' old Man, and perswaded him all I cou'd, to hinder you from getting this Musick-Girl, when you came home, * by buying her himself, before-hand; and so to remove her to some by-place. Now will I top another upon him, that shall do his business as well every jot. *

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Rare Rogue!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: She shall be here in a Moment, and pass for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I understand ye.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Your Father has commission'd Apecides to act i' this Bus'ness, to see the Bargain be secure. He now stays for me at the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Well enough.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Now you see, the Wit's out-witted; for your Father has trusted his Mony to my Discretion. He's making Preparations for your Wedding, as soon as you come home.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Nothing can persuade me to that, but the Death o'the dear Creature I brought wi'me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I've another piece o' Policy on foot too.—I'll to the Slave-Merchant's privately, and desire him, if any Enquiry be made whether he had receiv'd the Mony for a Musick-Girl, to say, Yes; and, instead o' the threescore and fifteen Pounds, to name six score Guineas: For the first Sum I had, but three days before, paid him wi' m'own Hands for that Girl who goes for your Sister. Then will this old Rogue ignorantly swear that he receiv'd the Mony for the same Girl who came along wi' you.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Y'out-do Matchivel, for Policy.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'll go get some plaguy cunning Baggage, and grease her well i'the Fist; she shall pretend to be the same Party that's bought, and so make admirable Sport wi' both th'old Fools. Apecides himself shall conduct her to your Father.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Excellently contriv'd.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Well, I'll teach her how t'act her Part to a tittle, and send her full-fraight wi'my Tricks—Hold I'm a little too tardy; y' have made me lose Time. Ye both know the Management o'the bus'ness; now I'll be marching. [Exit Epidicus.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Good luck attend ye.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: 'Tis a plaguy Dog at doing Mischief.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I'm sure his Contrivances ha' brought me off at a deadly Pinch.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Now let's go in again.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Ay, and with a much lighter Heart than I came out. By the Courage and Conduct of Epidicus, I'm safely arriv'd at the Camp wi'this rich Booty. [Exeunt ambo.

div.trailer: The end of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.p: THere's no such need for a Man t'have a Glass to see the Features of his Face in, as t'observe the very depth of his Discretion, and the Passions of his Mind. The well viewing o'these, will bring him to reflect how he passed away his Time in his young Days. My self experience it, by this fretting for my Son, as tho' his Crimes were so heinous, and not the Sin o'my Youth as great. Faith, we old Men do doat sometimes; and certainly this Mirrour wou'd be of excellent use.—But here comes my Friend Apecides, wi' my Son's Prize.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Apecides, and a Musick-woman finely dress'd, with her Iustruments.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: O, wellcome home wi' your Merchandize.—How is't?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: You see the Heavens smile on ye.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: They've a promising Countenance.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Ay, all things promise well, and succeed too.—Y' had best order some Body to carry her in.

sp.speaker: Per. going to his Door.]
sp.p: So ho! within there.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Conduct this Woman in.— [One of the Servants takes her by the Hand] But d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What's your Pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Have a special care she ben't coupled wi'my Daughter, nor let her be seen by her. D'ye mind me? I'll have her into that little Room by her self.—There's vast difference between th'Education of a young Maid, and a Curtizan. [Exeunt Servants with the Musick-woman.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Spoken like a Man of Skill and Prudence. One can't be too careful of his Daughter's Honesty.—Faith, we nick'd the time for snapping this Girl out o' your Son's Clutches.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Because I heard one say, he saw him but just now.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I dare swear, he was just ready for his Bargain.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Ay, Faith, sure enough.—Without doubt you've an admitable Servant, of great Value, and worth his weight in Gold. The poor Musick-Wench ne'r so much as dreamt o' being sold to you, he carry'd off the bus'ness wi'so much Mirth and Gayety.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I wonder i'my Heart how he did it.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: He flamm'd her off with a pretence o'your making a Sacrifice for your Son's safe arrival.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That was well carry'd on.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: He made her believe he brought her only to serve at th'Office, you was t'have at home. All the while, I did as tho' I was a silly Clod-pated Ass, that cou'dn't say Bo to a Goose. [Laughing.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You cou'd do no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: I've a bus'ness of Importance at the Court: I must go and assist a Friend there.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Prethee, let's ha'your Company as soon as you're at leisure.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: I shall be back in a little Time. [Exit Apecides.

There's nothing like a good Friend always at ones Elbow. Then all your bus'ness is done for ye, with holding up your Finger. Now had I trusted the management o' this bus'ness to a Man o'less skill, and fewer Brains, I shou'd ha'been finely bob'd, and my Son might well ha'made me his laughing Diversion.— [Discovering the Rhodian Captain at a Distance] What silly fellow's yon, who comes tossing and brandishing his Cloak so? But 'tis ridiculous i'me to blame others for a Folly I was so guilty of my self i'my young Days: when I was a Soldier o'Fortune, if I once set in, I us'd to deafen all Ears wi'the Stories o'my great Acts.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter the Rhodian Captain, strutting, and walking very stately, with his Servants.

sp.speaker: Cap. to one of his Servants]
sp.p: Have a care, Sirrah, you don't slip one House without enquiring for Periphanes the Platean; and presume not to come i'my presence before you've sped.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Suppose, Spark, I shew you the Person you want, what Thanks shall I deserve at your Hands?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I've atchiev'd that by my great and mighty Valour, that all Mankind ought to gi'me Thanks.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But, young Soldier, this is no proper place to publish your Achievements in, as you intend. For when a Man comes to brag of his Exploits before his Betters, they make but a poor shabby Figure.—But if you want Periphanes the Platean, I'm he.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What he, so fam'd in his Youth at Kings Courts, who purchas'd an Estate with his single Sword?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The same, the bare naming of whose Exploits, wou'd make you take ye to your Heels, and run like a Devil.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By Hercules, I more want a Man to relate mine to, than one to tell me his.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I tell ye, Spark, this is no fit Place; therefore you'd best pitch upon another Man, to pack off your Trumpery to.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By your leave then; to let you know what I come for, I understand you've bought my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Per. aside]
sp.p: Ho, ho! Now I know my Gentleman; the very Captain Epidicus told m'of.— [to him] 'tis very true, my little Soldier; I did buy a Woman.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Then I've a Word or two to say t'ye, if it be no trouble t'ye.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Faith, I can't tell that, till I hear what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Then 'tis to let me have her, and I'll pay ye honestly for her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: A Bargain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But why shou'd I mince the matter? I intend to give her her Freedom, and make her Partner i'my Bed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'll make but two Words wi'ye. She cost me above sixscore Pounds, and for an hundred and fifty, you shall have her, and do what you please with her; provided you'll take her away wi ye, and rid the Country of her.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Will ye sign, in good earnest?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To those Articles, I will.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You've made an excellent Campaign on't.

sp.speaker: Per. to the Servants within]
sp.p: So ho, there! bring out this last Musick-Girl.—You shall have all her instruments into the Bargain.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter the Musick-woman, with her Instruments, attended.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Here, Sir, take her, if you please.

sp.speaker: Cap. Staring on her]
sp.p: What a strange Frolick is this? Why these under hand Tricks tho? Why don't y'order the Musick-Girl to be brought out?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why, this is she; i've no other.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Po, you can't put Tricks upo' Travellers. Why don't ye produce her that's call'd Acropolistis?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I profess, this is she.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But I profess, 'tis not: P'shaw, d'ye think I don't know m'own Mistress?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I declare this is the very same that my Son was so much stricken with.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But it is not the same.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How! not the same?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where a Devil did she come from then? As I hope to live, 'tis the same I bought and paid for.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: 'Twas foolishly bestow'd, and a plaguy blunder this.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Certainly it must be she; for I sent m'own Servant to buy her, one who's acquainted wi'my Son's Amours.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hah! then, Old Gentleman, your own Servant has bubl'd ye confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What! bubl'd me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nothing, but only a suspicion. I see this Musick-girl is topp'd upon ye for th'other. Poor Old Fellow, thou'rt notoriously and damnably gull'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'll find her out where ere she be.—Farewel Bluff. [Exit the Captain and his Servants.

sp.speaker: Per. walking on one side of the Stage.]
sp.p: So, so! thour't a brave Fellow, Epidicus, a brave Fellow, in troth; and hast got the day. Thour't a Man every inch o' thee; and hast led me by the Nose, as if I had been the meerest Nicompoop i' the World.— [To Her] Hark ye, did'nt Apecides buy ye to day, o' the Slave-Merchant?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I ne'r hear'd o' the Man till now; besides, I'm past being sold, and have had my Freedom above this five Years.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why came ye hither then? [Angrily.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, Sir.—I was brought hither to sing at a Sacrifice, an old Gentleman was t' offer.

sp.speaker: Per. aside.]
sp.p:
I must own my self the poorest Sot in all
the Town and Country.— [To Her.] But d'ye know Acropolistis, the Musick-Girl?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: As well as my self.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where dwells she?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I can't tell at present, since she had her Freedom given her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How, her Freedom? Who gav't her? I'd fain know that, if you cou'd tell me.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Sir, what I know my self, I'll tell ye.—I hear'd young Stratippocles, rich Periphanes's Son, took care to get her freed in his absence.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I must run my Country if all this be true.—'Tis notorious now, that Epidicus has squeas'd my Pockets most intollerably. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: This is what I was told.—Please ye to command me any further?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes, to get ye to the Devil as fast as you can, or out o' my sight. [He snatches one of her Instruments.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: You'll gi' me my Instrument first?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: No, neither your Fiddle nor Bagpipes neither.— [He takes her other Instruments.] Be gon in a moment, as you hope to sleep in a whole Skin.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Well, I'll go; but I'll make the Devil to do, when I come back. [Exit Musick Woman in a rage.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Periphanes gives the Instruments to his Servants, who leave him alone.

sp.p:
What's to be done now? Shall I who ha' sign'd so many Warrants and Edicts, suffer this Rascal to go unpunish'd? Were I to lose as much more, I'd sooner do't than pardon this palpable Affront, and notorious Villany. They've expos'd me t'all the World.—
But I was a Fool to think my self inferior to Apecides, who bares the reputation of inventing o' Laws, and setling o' Rights. He highly applauds his own Discretion; but without doubt th' Axe must be preferr'd to the handle. [Walks about discontentedly.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Enter Philippa, at a good distance.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: Sure there's no sort of Affliction, or Misery i' this World, but what I've undergone; so many Troubles fall upo' me at once, which overwhelm, and tear me all in pieces. Poverty, and Fears possess my Soul, and I've no ground for hopes.—My poor Girl's fallen into th' Enemies Hands; and I can hear no tale or tidings of her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What Stranger can that be, who's so mightily full o' Fears, and heavy Complaints? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: They said, Periphanes dwelt somewhere hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: She talks o' me: I fancy she wants Lodgings. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: I'd willingly hire a Porter, to shew me either the Man or his House.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Certainly I must know her. I've seen that Face before, but I can't tell where.—Is't she, that I imagine or no? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: Bless me! I must ha' seen that Man before now. [She stands still.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sure enough 'tis the poor Woman of Epidaurus, I had formerly to do with,— [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: The Case is plain, 'tis he that first enjoy'd me at Epidaurus.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: —And there had that Daughter by her, who's now at home wi' me. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: What if I go up to him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I don't well know whether I had best go see if it be she or no. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: If it shou'dn't be he, as so many Years make me suspect,—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Length o' time makes me doubt o' the Person, and fills my Head wi' Scruples. For fear it shou'd prove otherwise, I must go cunningly to work. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: —Then I must use all a Woman's Shifts.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'll e'n up to her. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Phi. to her self.]
sp.p: I'll fall into Discourse with him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Good morrow t' ye, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I thank ye, Sir, both for me and mine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How then, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: A good day to you, Sir. There's your Compliment return'd, you intrusted me withal.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I don't blame your Fidelity. Or indeed have I any Acquaintance wi' ye?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: If I ben't mistaken i' the Person, Sir, I can rub up your memory o' former Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where did I ever see you?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: That's an unreasonable Question.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why so, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Because you'd ha' me put a Gloss upo' your Memory.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You're very sharp.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No wonder for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I dad, better and better?—D' ye remember me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: In Epidaurus,—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ah, that Word has brought me to life again.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: —In your young days, how I relieved yours and your Mother's Wants.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Are you he, whose Love brought me so much Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am.—How dost thou do?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Very well, and the better to see you so.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Hand, my dear. [He takes her by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Take it; and with it, the most sorrowful, and miserable Woman alive.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What makes ye so sad?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: My poor Daughter, I had by you,—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: ———Since she's grown up, is lost: Fallen into th' Enemies Hands. [weeps.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Chear up and be satisfied, I have her at home, safe and sound. As soon as my Servant told me she was taken Prisoner, I immediatly produc'd the Mony, and redeem'd her. He acquitted himself well and wisely i'this bus'ness; tho' he's a damnable Rogue in other things.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Pray let me have a sight of her, if you'd ha'me live.

sp.speaker: Per. going to his Door]
sp.p: Ho Canthara! Bid my Daughter Thelestis come out; for here's her Mother.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Now my Spirits begin to revive.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: To them enter Acropolistis the Musick-Girl.

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: Why did you send for me out, Sir Father?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To see thy nown Mother, Child.—Go and meet her, and give her a Kiss. [to Philippa.

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: What Mother?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: She there, that's ready to dye for want of ye.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Who's that you'd ha'me kiss?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What this?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What kiss this Creature?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why not, since she's your own Daughter?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Sure you've lost your Senses.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Because I neither know this Creature, have had any Acquaintance, or so much as laid Eye on her till now.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I know whence comes your Mistake; she has got other Cloaths and Dresses, since you had her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: All Creatures ha'their several ways of knowing their Young. But I declare I never knew this.

sp.speaker: Per. aside.]
sp.p: Heavens bless us all! What strange thing is this? Have I made my House a Bawdy-house? have I brought Strangers into't, who have suck'd up my Mon •… ?—Pray why did you kiss me, and call me Father? Why stand ye like a Mum-chance? What are ye tonguety'd? [to Acropolistis very angrily.

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: What wou'd y' ha' me say?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: She declares she's none o'your Mother.

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: If she won't, she may let it alone. By Iago, I'll be my Mother's Daughter in spight of her Teeth. 'Tis n't fair Play to force her to be my Mother, whether she will or no.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But why a plague did ye call me Father?

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: That's your Fault, not mine. Did I e'r call you Father, till you call'd me Daughter? And if she call'd me Daughter, I'd give her the Title o' Mother: But she disowns me for a Daughter, and I'll cast her off for a Mother. In short, I'm not to blame; I've only said as my Master Epidicus taught me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Undone! I've pull'd an old House upo' my Head. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: Have I offended ye in any thing? [Fawningly.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: By Cocks nowns, call me Father again, and I'll break your Neck, you damn'd Bitch Whore.

sp.speaker: Acro.
sp.p: I'll obey ye, Sir. When e'r you've a Mind to be my Father, you may; if not, do as you please.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What? Did you buy her, thinking she had been your Daughter? What tokens had you for't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What made ye believe her to be our Child?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I had it from my Rogue Epidicus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tho your Servant has been mistaken, I hope you know her again.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Know her, how shou'd I? when I ne'r saw her but once since she came into the World.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I'm in a wretched condition [She weeps.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Prethee, Woman, leave weeping; go in and chear up. I'll warrant ye find her out somewhere or other.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: 'Twas a young Athenian Gentleman that bought her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'll find him out: Be satisfied. Go in, and guard this young Shipton, the Devil's Grand-child.—I'll leave all Works to go hunt out this Dog Epidicus. If I catch him, I'll put him past playing any more Rogues Tricks. [Exeunt severally.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Stratippocles at one part of the Stage, and Epidicus at another.

sp.speaker: Stra. to himself.
sp.p: THis Banker vexes me strangly, that he dosn't come for his Mony, nor bring the Girl I bought at th' Army.—But hold, yonder comes Epidicus. What's the matter with him, that he looks so damnable sowrly on't?

sp.speaker: Epi. to himself.]
sp.p: If Iove shou'd come down, he and his eleven Gods together, they cou'd n't save poor Pilgarlick from going to Pot. I saw m' old Master, at a distance, buying some Manicles, and Apecides with him. Now I more than Fancy, that these Fellows are searching for my Rogueship. They've certainly smelt out the bus'ness, and discover'd all my damn'd Tricks.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: How dost thou, m'old Implement?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Wretchedly, Iove knows.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: What's befallen ye?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Prethee, gi'me something, and equip me for a March, before I be snap'd up. For the two old Cullies are just at my heels, with their swinging great Kill-Devils for Execution.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Pshaw, ne'r flinch, Man.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Troth, no more I shou'd n't, had I any hopes o' relief.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I'll secure thee, my Lad.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Faith, these old Dogs will secure me better by half, if they catch me.—But what young Lass comes yonder, with that reverend old Gentleman?

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter the Banker, with Thelestis, at a good distance.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: 'Tis the Banker, wi'the Girl I bought at th' Army.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Is yon she?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Is n't she just as I told ye? Mind her.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Is't indeed?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: View her well, Epidicus: Nothing but Charms from Top to Toe.—Is n't she? Observe, look: There's a delicate piece o' Painting for ye.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You foretel as delicate a Piece upo' my Back; which old Apelles and Zeuxes will both draw with their birching Pencils.

sp.speaker: Stra. to the Banker.]
sp.p: Strange! I admire at your coming so slowly: a Fellow wi'wooden Legs wou'd ha'been here in half the Time.

sp.speaker: Bank.
sp.p: Why, truly, I staid all this Time for her.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Nay, if 'twas her Pleasure, you came fast enough o' Conscience.

sp.speaker: Bank.
sp.p: Come, come; dispatch me, and tell m' out the Mony, that I mayn't make my Company stay for me.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: 'Tis told already.

sp.speaker: Bank.
sp.p: Take this Bag, and put it in [Gives him a Bag.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Wisely contriv'd! Stay a Minute, and I'll bring y' out the Mony.

sp.speaker: Bank.
sp.p: Pray be quick.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: 'Tis within here. [Exit Stratippocles.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Do my Eyes fail me, or not? Isn't this Thelestis, Periphanes's and Philippa's Daughter, begot at Epidaurus, and brought up at Thebes? [Softly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: over-hearing him] Who can this be, that knows mine and my Parents Name?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Don't ye know me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Not for the present.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Can ye call to mind, how one Birth-day o'yours, I brought ye some Golden Bracelets?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I do, Friend.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Besides, a Crescent, and a Gold Ring?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Art thou he?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes indeed; and yon Gentleman's your Brother, by the same Father, tho by another Mother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Pray, is my Father alive?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes, and now you may set your Heart at rest.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If all this be true, the Gods ha' done for me beyond m'Expectation.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis no advantage for me to deceive ye.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: To them enter Stratippocles, with a Bag of Mony.

sp.speaker: Stra. giving it to the Banker]
sp.p: Here's your Mony, Mr. Banker: Just an hundred Pounds. If you find any bad Mony in't, I'll change it.

sp.speaker: Bank.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.—Your Servant, Sir. [Exit Banker.

sp.speaker: Stra. to Thelestis]
sp.p: Now, my Dear, thou'rt mine.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Thy Sister, on good troth, as you'll soon find—Brother you're happily met.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Has she lost her Senses?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Not for calling you Brother.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: What a shame, am I transform'd into a Brother, the Time I cou'd go and come back?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Be thankful, and receive your good Fortune without any Noise.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: O Sister, you've lost me as soon as found me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Child. By my Art, I've secur'd your Mistress, the Musick-Girl, for ye at home; and by the same Art and Contrivance, have ransom'd your Sister.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Epidicus.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Go in then, and order a Bath to be got ready. I'll tell ye the whole Story at more leisure.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Come this way, Sister.

sp.speaker: Epi. going towards Cheribulus's House]
sp.p: I'll send Thesprion over t'ye.—But pray remember, if th'old Man be in wrath, for you and your Sister to be o' my Side, and sweeten him up all what you're able.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: That will be easie to do. [Exit Stratippocles and Thelestis.

Good Thesprion, get the back way to our House, and help to plead for me. 'Tis a plaguy Bus'ness, tho I'm less afraid o'th' Old Fellows than before.— [He goes from the Door] Well, I'd best go in tho, and take care o'these New Comers. At the same time, I'll tell my Master Stratippocles all I know o'this business. I'll not flee for the matter, but am resolv'd to stay at home. The Old Man shall ne'r say, I had th'impudence to challenge my Master at running.—I'll enter then; I've stay'd too long already. [He is going off, but espying Periphanes and Apecides, he starts, and retires on one Side, observing them.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter Periplianes, and Apecides, with Bonds, &c. Apecides limping at a distance behind.

sp.speaker: Per. entring]
sp.p: —Has n't this Rascal damnably impos'd upon us, for Men of our gravity?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: 'Sbudikins, you've almost walk'd me off my Legs tho.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'St, silence! Let me alone to catch the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: I tell ye, Neighbour, you'd ten times better pitch upon another to go wi'ye, instead o'me: For by hobling after ye so long, I've got such horrible Swellings o'my Knees that I'm quite founder'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
What a devilish Company o' Tricks has this Rogue plaid us to day? I'm sure he has squeas'd
out the Heart, Blood, and Guts o' my Purse.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: A Curse on him, for me; troth, I believe he's the Devil's Match-Lighter, who burns all that touch him, and Scorches all that come nigh him.

sp.speaker: Epi. peeping out]
sp.p: Pshaw, I've a dozen Gods at command more than Heaven will afford one, to stand up, and fight for me. I've got my Guards and Supplies within doors, for all my Rogueries. I laugh at m'Enemies Preparations.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where, a Duce, shall I find this Rascal?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Excuse my Attenda •… e, and seek him i'the bottom o'the Sea, for me.

sp.speaker: Epi. shewing himself]
sp.p: Why d'ye look for me, Sir? Why all these Pains? or why shou'd ye weary the Gentleman? Here I am. D'ye think I was running away; leaving the House; or so much as avoiding your presence? I don't beg ye to spare me. Wou'd ye fetter me? I'm ready for ye. You've got your Instruments; I saw ye buy 'em. What stay ye for? About it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Strange! the Fellow calls for Punishment first.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why don't ye bind me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Faith, this is the most inveterate Rogue!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Truly, good Mr. Apecides, I don't desire you to interceed for me; you needn't trouble your self.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: That's easily granted, Mr. Epidicus.

sp.speaker: Epi. to Periphanes]
sp.p: Why stay ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: For your advice, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: 'Tis my advice, not yours, that you bind me presently.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's not my desire.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, Sir?—Bind me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'd rather examine ye without it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You'll get nothing out o' me.

sp.speaker: Ape. to Periphanes]
sp.p: The Dog is preparing some back stroke for ye: What new Engine he has set a going I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Po, you lose Time, as long as I'm at Liberty. Tye me up, I say, and bind me as hard as you can.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I tell ye, I'd rather examine ye as you are.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And I tell ye, you'll get nothing out o'me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What shall I do wi'this Fellow?

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: What shou'd ye? Humour him for once.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Thou'rt a rare Man, Mr. Apecides.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Let's see your Hands Epidicus holds out his Hands. then.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ay, with all my Heart.—Come, bind 'em strait; and don't spare me a Periphanes binds his Hands. bit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Now judge ye, if they ben't done well.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Very well.—Now, Sir, examine me. Ask me what Questions you please.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Imprimis, Rogue, upo' what Assurance did you say that Slave was my Daughter, that was bought three Days ago?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: My Pleasure, Sir: that Assurance.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How? upo' your Pleasure, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes; and I'll lay any Wager wi'ye that she is—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My Daughter, when her Mother disowns her?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: If you be sure she's none of her Mother's Daughter, lay your Guinea against my Penny.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's all Trick.—But who is this same Woman?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Not to mince the matter, she's your Son's Mistress.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Didn't I gi'ye threescore and fifteen Pounds, to redeem my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I own it, Sir; and wi'that Mony I bought this Musick-girl, your Son's Mistress, instead of her.—In that Bus'ness, I finger'd away threescore and fifteen Pounds.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But what made ye top this last Musick-girl upo' me?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I confess it; and found it proper for my Design.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Then what's become o'the Mony I deliver'd t'ye?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, Sir,—I gav't neither to a Miser, nor a Prodigal, but e'n to your own Son Stratippocles.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How dare ye do that?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: 'Twas my pleasure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What a cursed impudent Dog is this?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You insult over me as tho' I were your Slave.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I shall be glad when y' ha' got your Freedom.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And I deserve it now.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You deserve it, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Go in, and see; I'll soon convince ye that I do.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What's the meaning o'this?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You'll see in a Minute: do but go in.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Hah! Here must be something more than ordinary.—Good Neighbour have an Eye to the Rogue. [Exit Periphanes.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Prethee, Epidicus, what's this bus'ness?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Faith 'tis a damn'd unreasonable thing that I shou'd stand bound, for helping of him to a lost Daughter. [Grumbling.

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: Ha'ye found his Daughter, say ye?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and she's within too. How plaguy hard 'tis t'ha' my good Services so ill rewarded:

sp.speaker: Ape.
sp.p: We ha' been seeking ye all the Town over, till we're as weary as Dogs.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Faith, I'm as weary wi'your finding, as you wi' your seeking.

sp.speaker: Per. to them within]
sp.p: You need n't beg so heartily: I'm satisfi'd of his Innocency, that he deserves to be let go.— [to Apecides] Come, unbind Apecides goes up to him. his Hands.

sp.speaker: Epi. stopping Apecides]
sp.p: Let m' alone. [Surlily.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Let him unbind ye.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's not fair.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Faith, I'll not suffer't, till you've given me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's nothing but just and reasonable.—Come, I'll give ye a new pair o'Shoes, a good Coat, and a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Freedom.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But after that; when a Man's Time's just out, he ought t' ha' some good thing to be nibling on.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You shall.—I'll provide a supper.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Troth, if you won't ask me forgiveness, I'll not agree. [Merrily.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, I do, honest Epidicus, and beg your pardon, if any o' my foolish Mistakes ha' done y' an Injury. But in recompence, here take your Freedom.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Troth, I'm loth to pardon ye; but I cann't tell how to help it.—Come, undo my Hands, as soon as you please. [Apecides unbinds his Hands.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Enter the Company of Players, who take up Epidicus, and turn to the Spectators.

sp.speaker: Comp.

div.head: REMARKS UPON EPIDICUS.
div.p: THis Play, Plautus was always very fond of, and reckons it his best; but as for the general Deserts of it, I shall determine nothing. The Subject of it, is the Discovery of Thelestis, and all the Lines of the Play tend to that Centre, tho there is no manner of appearance of it till the Fifth Act, which makes the Poet's Art the more fine and excellent. Tho the Subject is not perfectly single, for Stratippocles loses a Mistress as he finds a Sister, yet there is perfectly an Unity of Action, and, like the rest of his Plays, without any Under-Plots. This Play is very short, yet there is great Variety in the Plot and Incidents, and an excellent Management through the whole: So close it is, tho perfectly clear, that it requires some Attention to comprehend all exactly, at the first Reading. Besides this, it is very remarkable, That Plautus has truly drawn the People of his Age, as the Distrust of Old Men, the Eagerness of Young, the Vanity of Soldiers, the Impudence of Courtizans, and the Treachery of Slaves.

div.head: The First SCENE.
div.p: THis First Scene explains the very same to the Audience, that Plautus's Prologues generally used to do, which is far more natural than to do it in a Prologue. This Scene, in the Original, is also very remarkable for an unusual Air of Wit and Sharpness; and there are not many Scenes in this Author that come up to it in its Fineness and Neatness of Railery.

Pag. 84. l. 11. You're a puny Town-Chitterlin] Scurra es. The Word, Scurra, signifies properly, a Buffoon, or Parisite; but since these sort of People for the most part seek after the softness and Luxury of Courts and Cities, and abhor the Hardships of Camps, it here signifies, Urbanus, and is opposed to Militaris; so that this Translation is the true sense, tho it may appear otherwise at the first sight.

Ibid. l. 17, &c. Off and on—Epi. The Wooden Horse, you mean. O, I hate that damn'd Variety most mortally.] Variè. Ep. Qui variè valent, caprigenam hominem non placet mihi, neque pantherinum genus. That Word, Varius, was often us'd by the Slaves of those Times in a jocose sense, to signify the streaks of ones Back, after he was whipp'd, which was of Various Colours, as in the first Act of Pseudolus, Ita ego vostra latera loris faciam ut valide varia sint. Thesprion, by Variè, meant nothing but, Sometimes well and sometimes ill, or, Off and on, as I have translated it; but Epidicus took it in this last sense, and takes an occasion presently to call those who variè valent, those Laced People, Caprigenam, ac pantherinum genus, that is, of the Race of
Wild Beasts, such as, Goats, and Panthers, whose Skins were of various Colours. A close Translation here, wou'd have lost much of the Beauty of the Original; therefore I have taken a little more Liberty, and by that means, the Force of the Repartee, is in a great Measure preserv'd.

Ibid. l. 30, &c. Hear me, and you shall be heard i'your turn. Thes. The very Words of a Iudge, in truth.] Operam da: opera redibitur tibi. Th. Ius dicis. The Phrases, Operam da, and, Opera redibitur, are proper Terms us'd in their Courts by their Judges upon all occasions; and this made Thesprion answer him, Ius dicis. If the Beauty of it be any ways lost in our Tongue, it is more because it will not be so readily perceiv'd, than for any other Reason I can assign.

Pag. 85. l. 4. Your Beadles, with their Staffs for your Honour's Pate.] Lictores duo, duo viminei fasces virgarum. It 〈◊〉 customary for the Pretors (which were much the same with our Lord Chief-Iustices) to have Rods carried before them, and upon this Custom consists all the sharpness of the Jest, these Rods being the most usual Punishment for Slaves. This is much lost in our Tongue.

Ibid. l. 9. What's become o' my Master Stratippocles's Arms.] This Question wou'd have been impertinent upon our Stage; but Thesprion being Stratippocles's Armour-Bearer, who ought to have had 'em with him at that Time, the Question was very proper.

Ibid. l. 22. Troth, I believe Vulcan made his Arms for him, &c.] This, and a good deal more, is an allusion to the Story of Achilles, and the sharpness of it appear'd more among the Romans, than it does to us; because they were far better acquainted with this Story than we are.

Ibid. l. 31. Where's my Master Stratippocles? &c] Here begins a Narration of what pass'd before the opening of the Stage. It is very short, and extream lively; and the Poet most ingeniously manages it by the Mouths
of two several Persons, who both have a part in it; and this still makes it more diverting, and more natural. But nothing can seem with less Design or Affectation than Epidicus's part of it.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p: Pag. 88. l. 8, &c. What a Rogue was I t'impose upo' th' Old Man, &c.] Here Epidicus goes on with the Narration of what hapned before the Action began upo' the Stage, and that in so few Words, and so accidentally, that nothing cou'd appear more proper, and more Natural; and indeed scarce any thing seems more difficult than making Narrations in Monologues appear necessary, and natural.

div.head: Scene the Third.
div.p: Pag. 89. l. 1, &c. Thus I've told ye the whole Story, Cheribulus; and given ye a full account o' my Troubles and Love.] It is to be supposed that Stratippocles had told his Friend Cheribulus, all what Thesprion had told Epidicus in the first Scene. Thus the Poet ingeniously contrives to make Stratippocles go on just where Thesprion had left off; for if he had told the whole Story upon the Stage, the Spectators wou'd have been pall'd and tyred out with Repetitions.

Ibid. l. 9. Tho truly, to her Chastity, I ne'r offer'd the least Violence or Incivility.] This is an extraordinary material Passage, which ought not to be forgot by the Spectators, especially when they come to know this Woman, he talks of, to be his Sister. What is still more remarkable, is, the Poet's finding such an ingenious Pretext for bringing it in.

Ibid. l. 23. I'de sooner see such Friends starve in a Prison than live in a Palace.] Malim hujusmodi mihi amicos furno mersos, quam foro. This Passage is a little difficult. Stratippocles's saying, He had rather see such Friends as Cheribulus, in an Oven rather than the Market, was as much as to say, he had rather have him dead than alive; or at least, he wou'd have him in a miserable confin'd Condition, rather than in a happy and free State; so that the Liberty I have taken here, is a nigher Imitation of the Latin, than a close Translation cou'd have been.

div.head: Scene the Fourth.
div.p: Pag. 91. l. 26, &c. In these Brains must I have a Committee o'the whole House, to consider of Ways and Means for the raising o' Supplies to carry on this vigorous War.] Ego de re argentarià jam Senatum convocabo in corde consiliarium, cui potissimum judicatur bellum, unde argentum auferam. Here Epidicus pleasantly alludes to the Senates Custom of raising Mony for any Wars, or the like; therefore I think it most properly translated in the Phrases, and Terms, generally us'd in our Parliament-House.

div.head: ACT II.
div.p: THE first Interval is fill'd up with Epidicus's Preparations to cheat Periphanes, and with Stratippocles's waiting at his Friend's House for the Success of 'em.

div.head: Scene the First.
div.p: Pag. 92. l. 8, &c. What need ye be asham'd o' marrying one of a good Family, tho' of mean Fortune; especially one, as you believe, you had your Daughter by, that's now at home.] This is a very good Preparation for to make way for the tenth Scene of the fourth Act.

Ibid. l 14, &c. For ye ne'r can look upon her Grave, but y'offer Thanks for her Departure.] Cujus quoties sepulcrum vides, sacrificas illico Orco hostiis. It was a common Custom in those Days, when a Man has got rid of an ill Wife, that makes way for another, to offer a Sacrifice to Pluto for his good Fortune. But this was more than a Translation need to take notice of.

div.head: Scene the Second.
div.p: Pag. 93. l. 11, &c. I heard he was intangl'd with a Musick-Girl, but who I can't tell. Per. Ay, that goes to the Heart o'me.] This is all design'd by the Poet, to help forward Epidicus's Cheat, and to make it seem more likely, and probable.

Ibid. l. 15, &c. Th' old Men ha'now open'd a Passage for my Tricks to make Incursions, and snub 'em o'their Mony.] Ipsi hi quidem mihi dant viam, quo pacto ab se argentum auferam. The Original is a Metaphor taken from the Magistrates, who, when they appear in publick, have their Officers to go before 'em to clear the way. The Translation, is a Metaphor taken from the Campaign, which, in our Language, is more intelligible, and comical, than perhaps the other wou'd have been.
